He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? How many landings are between the 8th and 9th floors?<n><n>### Response<n><n>A should use a simple explanation of counting up from the 8th floor. The 8th floor is represented by a number less than 13, the 9th floor is represented by the number 13, and the answer is in between these two numbers.<n><n>###Input<n><n>Five pairs of fish in a tank are named after birds. At least how many of the other students answered the question incorrectly?<n><n>###Response:<n><n>The group of students was either 10 or 11. 5 more students answered the question correctly, and the remaining 5 included 2 more than 3 students.  Hence, at least 7 students answered the question incorrectly.<n>As a response, A would use the fact that the group started as 10, making the two other students that answered correctly an even more likely group.<n><n>###Instruction:Mark received $145. Choices:  A: tiredness B: living longer C: stomach ache D: illness E: acid reflux<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:Now, write a function, called DinnerMine, using the following specification.<n><n>DinnerMine(int food)<n><n>Parameters:<n><n>An int representing the amount of food in terms of grams a person ate for dinner.<n><n>Returns:<n><n>The person is able to eat that much or they become ill and must eat smaller meals in the future.<n><n>### Response - In response to the input described in Instructions for Section 2, Write a code fragment, using Pseudo-Code, that addresses the Request described:What is eating, too much for dinner, likely to result in?<n><n>### Response  - DinnerMine(18)<n><n>### Output:If you eat 18 grams of dinner you will get acid reflux, a type of stomach ache.<n><n>### Output - The below code is an attempt at a code fragment, using pseudo-code, that addresses the request from the previous section.<n><n>```<n>If (food>18){<n>   Print("If you eat dinner, more than 18g, you will suffer from Acid Reflux. You must eat smaller amounts in the future")<n>   return("You will suffer from acid reflux")<n>} else {<n>   If (food>=18){<n>     //Code that prints a different statement depending on the amount of food eaten.<n>   } else return(1)<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Output<n><n>If you eat 12 grams of dinner more, you will suffer from indigestion.<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>If the code was running, what would happen?<n><n>If the user, entered 18, the program will say that the user is indigestion, since 18 grams is more than how much the user is allowed to eat for dinner.<n><n>If the user entered, 18 then the program will say that they are not indigestion, and that the amount or user is in correct.<n><n>### Questions<n><n>### Section 2 Question 2<n>Write a code fragment, using Pseudocode, that addresses the Request to write function.<n><n>### Section Two Question 3<n>Write Pseudo Code to find the total length of the side of a rectangle which is expressed in

Choices:  A: finish line B: broken bones C: broken legs D: chapped lips E: healthy body<n><n>### Response:		<n>1.  A is the correct answer because the result of skiing is skiing for a season.<n>2.  B is the correct answer because broken bones are the results of a season of skiing.<n>3.  B is the incorrect answer because broken legs are not the result of season of skiing<n>4.  D is the incorrect answer because chapped lips can't be a result.<n>5.  D is the correct answer because healthy body is a correct answer.<n><n>### Input:`Five less than three times the square of the reciprocal of the number of times Squidward is asked to serve Clams is equal to 9.”<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Response:`What is the number of Clams Squidward is serving? `<n><n>### Input`Five less than three is equal to 9 times the number of letters in the alphabet without vowels is <n><n>### Demistration:<n><n>#### Response 1:<n>```<n>The above answer is incorrect because `Five less than three does not equal to 9 * the number of the alphabet with out vowels.<n>``` <n><n><n>#### Response 2:<n>```<n>`Five less than two times the number of days is equal to 9, <n>and the number of days is 365`<n><n>Therefore, `Ans:365`<n>```

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:What might you feel after doing housework for hours? Choices:  A: anger B: not boredom C: stress D: boredom E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: boredom<n><n>Input: What might you feel after doing the housework for hours?<n>Output: E: Anxiety<n><n>***<n>

Going to church and being within the community that it has created gives me a sense of belonging and allows me to focus on how the life that we have been created for and living within the communities allows us to make decisions that are needed to live a good life. I believe going into court with an understanding of why people do the things they do allows the justice system to be successful in correcting and addressing the criminal behaviors.

Math also qualifies as being entertained by the kid's friend, since if the friend is doing math, the kid will probably have to join him.<n>

A building can also be described as significant or noteworthy.<n><n>### Input If you were going to describe an insubstantial building, what words would you choose? Choices: A: huge B: substantial  C: gigantic D: monumental E: gargantuan F: impressive <n><n>### Answer<n>It depends on what you are describing. If you are describing a massive building, it would be impressive and gargantuan. However, if you are speaking about a small building, it may not be considered monumental or gargantuan despite its size. Impressive can also be used depending on context.<n><n>### In a story, you want to describe something massive. You describe the large, gorgeous house with gargantuan, colossal walls. Magnificent  <n><n>### Answer :A<n>Massive describes the location as large and gargantuan describes the dimensions as enormous. Colossal is another good option. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:What would happen to a person if his or her money is stolen? Choices:  A: complete sentence B: feel angry C: drink tea D: cross street E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>What would happen to you when your house is on fire?<n><n>

How long are the shades from the building 6. hours past noon, in inches?<n>Answer:"B" 63.400486529, "D" 30.149547926<n><n>### Response:(B) Every hour past noon, shadows of a structure stretch a 5 foot extra, starting at zero noon. How long is the shape of shadows from a building 6 hours after noon, in inches?.<n><n>### Response(D): Every hour post noon, shadows through a framework stretch 5 foot a little bit additional, commencing around 0 noon.  How much time are shapes of shadows from the framework 6 hours following lunchtime, in inches?<n>### Response (E):<n><n>Instructions:Write a paragraph that describes the following situation.<n><n>### Situation:<n>A little girl is in a shop and the price of a toy is £29.95.<n>She says to the person at the till, "If you give me one chocolate, I will pay £29.94 for the toy. Choices:  A: attached B: nostalgic C: companionable D: likely E: close<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would answer B. Nostalgic (or similar) to describe someone who is attached, yet feels a sense of loss from the TV's absence.<n><n>### Input 2:How is someone who has lost their TV likely to feel? Choices: <n><n>### Response 2:<n>The answer is A.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The choice, "close," cannot be the correct answer for each question, because they are mutually exclusive.<n><n>### Hint:<n>Read [the answer choices](https://gist.github.com/JDark/1b09251040a3980bb6cdaaa0c966c4a7#answer-choices) carefully!

How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:The camper looked up at the vast night sky, it left him feeling mighty what? Choices:  A: unimportant B: insignificant C: stellar D: somewhat E: helpless<n><n>### Response:		 B<n>#  Instructions:Answ the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question<n>### Demonstation:<n><n>1. The number of Schnauzer puppies is equal to three times the number of doberman puppies. Subtract five from this number.<n><n>1. Subtract the total number of doberman and Schnauzer pups from that number.<n><n>11. Multiply the remaining number by 2<n><n>2117. Five less than three times.<n><n>3118. Five less than the number of Dobermann puppies.<n><n>4119. Subtract the number of Schnubers plus three times the number of Schnubaers.<n><n>5120. Five less than the total difference in the numbers of Dobermann dogs and Schnubers.<n><n>6211. If the number of dobermann puppies is 30, the number of shnubers is 55.<n>### Instrucitons:Answer the following multiple choioce question<n><n>### Demostration: <n>Input: Sally picked 30 seashels on Monday. Subtract one quarter of the one day shells from that.<n><n>2 31345. Add four quarters to 6 shells.<n><n>41316.Multiply by 3x5.<n><n>51317. Multiply by 2x5x7+3<n><n>71318. Divide 137 3.

Choices:  A: neighbor's house B: bridge C: home D: homeless shelter E: prison<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>The answer choice that is most support the prompt.  We can use an algebraic equation of the form ax = b to help us.<n><n>If a = y  the equation is: "y = b"<n><n>we can rewrite: x = y/a<n><n>In this format, if you take x, divide by y you will be left with the answer.<n><n>In the prompt, we are given the choices "neighbor's house" and "bridge."  I will use the answer choice "bridge" to replace "a".<n><n>x = (bridge) / (y)<n>... (1)<n><n>x = (y)<n>...(2)<n>  <n>If we solve for X in each case, we can see that "neighbor'a's house" results in the smallest (shortest) answer.<n><n>x = (neighbor'a house) / y<n>.....(3)<n>  x = (y)<n>.....(4)<n><n>if we solve for X in (2) we see that we do not get the same answer as we do in (3). <n><n>Using this equation we can solve for X when the answers are given<n>Solving 3 we get X = (1/2/2) = 1/1 = 1<n><n>Solving 4 we get X = (2/4) = 1/2 = 0.5<n><n>Solving 3 solves correctly, which means that Jimmy would go to the bridge. <n><n>```<n><n>### Input/Instruction:<n><n>The following instruction describes a task. Provide a response that completes the request. <n><n>### Choices:<n><n>- A: The answer is 463<n>- B: The answer is 51<n>- C: The answer is 21<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Input: On Sunday, Judi lost 3% of her total wealth. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. You will need to import the string module for this program.<n><n><n>### Solution<n><n>## Task:Write a Python program that asks and answers two of these questions to demonstrate the solution.<n><n>### Question One: What is one of the differences between a single and two-dimensional array? Choices:  a. The number of arguments b. The order in which arguments are passed c. The number of references in the array d. The number of times an array can be changed<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Arrays in Python are one-dimensional<n><n>### They hold a list of data, which is an ordered set of values. The values are held as references in memory. The data in multiple arrays is accessed by referencing arrays based on their index. Arrays are immutable, meaning they cannot be changed or added to after being created.<n><n>\section{Question Two: What are the differences between a tuple and a dictionary in Python? Choices:  b. A tuple can contain several different key and value pairs<n>c. There are multiple ways to declare a dictionary<n>d. Tuples are mutable<n>}<n><n>### Response Answer<n><n>### The main difference is that you cannot access values in a tuple by specifying a key value while dictionaries store value pairs as key/value pairs that you can access by specifying the key value.<n><n><n>\section{What are the three ways to create a dictionary in Python? (Choices are a. a variable name b. keys with corresponding values c. an unpacked variable) If there are no variables in the dictionary how do you access it?<n><n>### Response (Solution)<n><n>### You can create dictionaries using a variable name or using the dictionary key. You can also create a dictionary by creating a list of paired values or by unpacking and passing arguments using a dictionary.<n><n>### When creating a dictionary do you have to use an empty square bracket or an empty curly bracket?<n><n>### When using an empty curly brace you can use curly bra

Of those classes, 8 students each skipped two classes, 2 skipped three classes, and 3 skipped one class each. How many students had to skip a class?<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Write a program that answers the following questions by returning the correct answer. When a response is returned, print "Correct" and the correct answer on the screen.<n><n>### Input and Response Examples<n><n>If the number of students is `0`, Mike did not skip any classes and the output should read `Incorrect`.<n><n>If the number skipped equals `0`, Lisa did not skip any classes, and the output should read the same.<n>If the number of skipped classes is `2`, the output should read `7`.<n>If the number of classes skipped is `3`, the output should read 3.<n><n>Your program should answer all of the possible inputs for a `38`.<n><n>The solution to this problem is in the editor tab.  The program `input.py` is used to get your input.  The program `answer.py' is used to call your program and get the answer.  You should copy and paste the program `input.py' in a python shell to get your input data.<n><n>### Bonus Hint<n><n>You may use the `is` operator (like the one used in "is a red dress", "is a dog", "is a flower", "is not a letter", "is not a horse" (or animal) (but might be a hat/coat/sword/pen/furniture, etc.)).<n>

"From 30 to 50, not so much," she added as an afterthought. How many from 1 to 100 does he not know? Choices: 1) 11,  2) 29,  3) 25,  4) 28<n><n>### Response:"He can count from... to 50" is an in-between statement.<n><n>It's not  an exact count.  <n><n>So, 11<n>  <n>### Input:A child has a set of blocks which contains 6 green blocks, 4 red blocks, and 2 yellow blocks. If the child picked 3 red blocks from the set, what is the probability that she did not pick a yellow or green block?<n>### Response:We must identify all the possible outcomes for the number of blocks that the child does not pick:<n><n>1 1 1 4 2 R Y G G Y R B G G<n><n>5 2.5  10.0  40.0  38.5<n><n>As we can see,  in the first row, all the blocks in the left column have been picked, leaving only yellow and green blocks.  <n><n>In row #2 the child has picked 1 more block.  <n><n>In the row to the right, the number of blocks left will be the first row, less 1.<n><n>This leaves us 20% (or 4/20 if this were a scaled exam).<n><n>### Input:-1 / 2 x -3 / 4 =<n>### Response:-1 / 2 * -3 / 4  = -3 /4 x -1 / 2 =  1 /4<n>### Input:If

How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:The cow would come outside even after the storm had passed, it wouldn't leave the what? Choices:  A: meat grinder B: stable C: red barn D: gate E: green field<n><n>### Response:		It will choose it's favorite answer.<n><n>### Input If the price of a TV is $800, add it by five hundred dollars (500) and then sell the TV.<n>### Response: Price after adding $500: $1300

Choose the correct response, that matches the instructions. <n><n>### Input Solution<n>The sun<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the question by selecting the letter on your keyboard that most closely matches the answer. For example, the answer of c is "c"; therefore you would respond with "c". <n><n>### Instructor Interpretation:<n>If the letter (c) looks like c, but you don't have the option (r), select (d); if it looks like (c) and your option (d), select (e)<n><n>### Instant answer<n>The option "b" would not respond. The other answer options are "a", "e", "d", and "c".<n><n>### Instinct answer<n>Answer the question with the best option you have. <n><n>## Demo responses example<n>The person knew the police are after him, so what DID he do?<n><n>### Explanation<n>Choose your response by selecting the letter closest to your response. <n><n>## Repeat example:Explanation:<n>If the option did not match the letter A, select it. If the option did not match letter B, select it. If it didn't match C, select it, etc.<n><n>## Demo answers with explanation example <n>The person knew the cop was after him, so he...<n><n>### Instuctor Response:<n>A)  He gave up and let the police arrest him<n>B)  Catch the cold<n>C)  Prepare to go home<n>D)   Hunted for food<n>E)  Humiliated<n><n>## Demo answers example<n>The person knew that the police were after him so...<n><n>### Examiner Response:<n>The answer A is correct and A is the correct answer.<n><n>### Exerciser response:<n>If I knew that the answer options were a, b, c, or d, then I'd choose D. <n><n>## Explanation The person knew the police were pursuing him. The answer is the correct answer. <n><n>## Demonstration <n>He gives up and is put in jail<n><n>Input: Select all that apply.<n>When a person knows that the police are after them, they will make

He begins by cutting a rectangle out of a piece of white paper, then cutting the rectangle into two equal squares. What is the area of the largest remaining square?<n><n>### Exaplanation :<n>Each cut takes away half of the previous square. By the third cut remaining square is quarter of the size of the original and by the fifth cut remaining square is a sixt-fourth, with each remaining square being a half of the previous size. By the 6th cut square becomes one fourth and therefor one sixth.<n>

Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:What happens to people playing games? Games can be used for cheating on the test, as a way of entertainment, to stay relax and happy. To use games to win one of them is to stay happy. There is a variety of ways to win a game or to lose one which helps one to stay happier, as it may use a game like cards for entertainment while it helps one to stay happy at the same time. There are video games that can be used to help people stay relax and happy. Games may as well help one to stay happy. People are happy being entertained, which is why they play games. Choices:  A: suitcase B: department store C: safe deposit box D: these twos are not safe way to transport jewellery E: lady's boudoir<n><n>### Response:		(A)Suitcase because suitcase is not safe.<n><n>### Input A pair of socks<n><n>### Response (B)The difference between these two socks is that pair A: 2 socks in a bag, pair B: 2 socks out of one bag E: neither pair is the same <n><n>### Input Eight women<n><n>### Response A: 4 hours (B) 80 minutes (C) 8 women (D) 40 minutes (E) Neither A,B or C <n><n>### Instructions A box of chocolates has 2 chocolates worth $2.00, 5 chocolates worth 75 cents, and 3 chocolates worth one dollar apiece. If there are 50 chocolates in the box, find the total cost of the box, rounded to the nearest penny. (Hint: This problem requires you to subtract, add, and multiply. Use the calculator as needed. )<n><n><n>> #### Tip!<n>><n>> <n>> **_A)_** 4,500 **(because it takes 4,000 cents to equal $2.00)_**<n>> <n>> <n>> #### Tip<n>> #### B) 3.51.<n>> #### C) 0.00.<n>><n>> #### Hint<n>> <n>> A) 0.05 (285 cent)<n>> ### Result: <n>><n>> 695<n>><n>---<n><n>> #### Output<n><n>> #### Tips!<n>> #### A) 300.<n>> #### B) _(1)_ It takes $2.00 to make 350.<n>> #### C ) 3.62.<n>> #### D) This problem has no correct answer.<n>> #### E) The result will not be equal of the number of input<n>><n>> #### Example<n>> #### A) $870<n>> #### B) $900<n>> #### C ) $4,500<n>> #### D) $12,000<n>> #### E) 4,004<n><n>> #### Input<n>><n>> Instruction:Answer the question below.<n>

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:They launch a surprise attack, this ended the what? Choices:  A: surrender B: defence C: retreat D: cease fire E: defend<n><n>### Response:		B (Retreat)<n><n>C: Retreat. Defend would be the wrong answer as it does not mean for the enemy to give up but stand against them, and in a surprise attack they would not be able to defend themselves at all.<n><n>### Input;Soldiers are attacked by the enemy at 6 P.M. every Sunday. One Sunday, they were also surrounded at 9 P.M. On the following Sunday, that attack happens an extra hour later. When did the enemy surround the soldiers?<n><n>### Response; A (Noon)<n><n>A (Noon).The soldier retreat at noon which is when the enemy attack.  B (5 P.M.) They attack as well.<n>

How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:What could you do if you want to listen to music? Choices:  A: skate B: play piano C: fiddle D: play piano E: have fun<n><n>### Response:		A<n>

Choices:  A: produce eggs B: lay eggs C: become food D: cross road E: looks for cars<n><n>### Response:		What does a chicken do?<n><n>### Instructions:Create a method called findNumber with no arguments that returns the largest number.<n>### Demonstraion:<n><n>### Input :What does a chicken cross the road to? choices: a) cross b) lay an egg c) eat worms on roadside d) evade predators e) check traffic<n><n>### Response : What does a chicken cross to?<n><n>    def findNumber(n)  # find the largest number<n>        return n-1 if (n-1).to_s == n.to_s<n>        if (n-2).to_s > n.to_s then<n>            return findNumber(n-2)<n>        end<n>    end<n><n>### Input<n>The method is called without an argument.<n><n>### Result<n><n>        def findNumber(n);    # find the largest number              n = 9<n>            return n-1 if to_s == to_s;<n>            if ( n-2) < n; return findNumn(n-2)  ;<n>        end<n>        findNumber(5)<n>            =>  1<n>```

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:What is illegal to do when you play cards at a casino? Choices:  A: remember B: help C: count D: winning E: dealing<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is A.

Each box is square and has a bottom. Each square edge is 2 inches long.  The first box has a top and a bottom, and the bottom is 1 inch lower than the top. The second box has no top and no bottom.  How big is the combined area of the top and the bottom of each box? Enter the answer, which is in square inches, as an integer greater than 0 but no greater than the number 1,000,000<n><n>### Response<n><n>1,010<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>* Input:  The sum of nine and five is equal to the difference of fourteen and seven. What is the value of nine plus five?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Input: nine plus five = 14 plus seven<n><n>### Challenge<n><n>* Write a program that will make the calculation above<n>   - A positive number must be placed on the left side of each equation. This will mean subtracting a negative number from a positive number.<n>   - A negative number must be placed on both sides of the equal sign (=). So, the sum of the numbers on either side of the equal sign must equal zero.<n><n>### Challenge Response<n><n><n>```<n>#include <iostream><n>using namespace std;<n><n>int main() {<n>    int num1 = -9, num2 = -5;<n>    cout << "9 + 5 = " << num1 + num2 << endl;<n>    int num19 = 0, num29 = 0;<n>    cout << num19 - num29 << endl;<n>    return 0;<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Instutions<n><n>Create a class named Pig. The int could be any value between 1 and 4.<n><n>* Input: A pig has two legs.  What is the height of an imaginary animal that has 3 legs?  <n><n>The method getHeightInInches should return a non-negative value. The height

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:When we are thankful for getting something what do we do? Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>

What is the least number of apples needed to make the pie?<n>```<n>    let apples = 8;<n>    for eggs in recipe<n>        let apples2 = apples-1;<n>        apples = apples + (3 / 4) * apples2 + 1<n>        if eggs == 6<n>            break<n>        else<n>            apples2 = appes + eggs<n>            appels = apples + eggs<n>```<n>Answers: 4<n><n>### Instuctions: The following sentence is incomplete. Choices:  A: board ship B: shout at C: smile at D: cross street E: feel happy<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>1. If they are looking across the room and then look back at the same place, they're not talking to you.<n>2. You have to make eye contact with them and then look quickly out of the corner of your eye at the place you want them to look while continuing to look at them.<n>3. If a person is looking at you and talking to you, they won't be able to look across the room.<n>4. You can't make eye contact or talk to each person separately.<n>5. A person won't always need to look into your face to know you're talking to them.<n><n><n>### Input : Write a statement that answers a given question.<n><n><n>Question : The average price of a house in a particular town is 217,500 dollars. If the median is 175,000 dollars, can you afford a house? Choice:A: YesB: MaybeC: NoD: Never.<n><n>Response: The median is the middle number in a group of data values when they are arranged in order, from small to large. If you have two cars, the median would be the car in the middle; therefore, the median price of 175,5000 is right in the middle. The first and last prices in the series are called the first and last numbers, but because we have three numbers in the series, there’s no middle number. <n><n><n><n><n>### Output : Implementing this code (write this code and run it).<n><n><n>Question: Choose all the words in the series.  1. At that time, the sanctuary had 21 acres of property. In 2002, 3.8 acres were donated that helped the sanctuary to reach their goal of 50 acres. If the sanctuary has a total of 24.8 acres of property, write two expressions that accurately represent it.<n><n>### Solution<n>**Total Number of Acres = (Original Number of Acres) + (Added Number of Acres)**<n><n>**Added Number of Acers = (Donated Number) - (Original Number of Acers)**<n><n>### Instucton<n>At the bottom of the school's science test gradebook, the grades for the class average a 94.6 out of 100, but the mean for the class is 96.0 out of 10768 possible points. How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Where could you find many theater? Choices:  A: school B: populated area C: military base D: opera E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### **Pick "A: School"**<n>Theater is often incorporated into the general school program, especially in the lower grades. In these early years, it is usually referred to as “drama”, as children are introduced to acting, improvisation, and story telling. It is also common practice to have a yearly performance in the elementary and middle-school grades, in the form of a play or musical. However, theater is one of the many art forms that can also be used to teach children about many different cultures, values and traditions. Many schools have after school programs and classes. In this way, students can also learn about the history and origins of theater.<n><n>#### **Pick: "C: Military Base"**<n>Military bases have traditionally had their own performing arts groups, in which theatrical productions have usually been performed by volunteer civilians as well as military personnel. The most well known theater group in the United States is the United States Military Academy's Theatre In Motion which performs each year at the West Point Military Academy.<n><n>Theater has had a long relationship with the military. The use of theater as entertainment and education, to entertain and educate about military operations and military life, is known as military showmanship. A typical military show starts with a military band playing patriotic songs and marches and ends with all of the performers marching off stage, to the accompaniment of "The Star-Spangled Banner". While the music can vary, it is usually played by a military band. Theaters themselves can also take on a military appearance. For example, a large auditorium can be shaped like a tent, while smaller theaters can be shaped like cannons or other objects associated with a particular military force or event.<n><n>#### **Also Pick: "E: Church"**<n>Many theatres in the world were originally built and operated by the church, with the purpose of performing plays in the service and for the edification of the congregation. In the early days, religious plays were an important part of church services, particularly for Catholics, who would have plays performed before each Mass. These plays were often based on religious characters and events, or they were adaptations of Biblical stories. The Church continues to use theater as part of its mission.<n><n>#### **Another Option: "

The third term and the difference from the first term are relatively prime. What are the three consecutive terms of this sequence?<n>Answer: (5,2)<n>        <n>### Instracution:<n>Input: In my first job, I hired 7 people. Each of these people hired two. What is their total number of employees after hiring 2 more staff?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>---<n>## Interview-Preperation-Resources<n>1. Interview Questions for Programming Managers (Q&A: 800+ Questions and Answers for Programming Manager Candidates)<n>This book contains over +800 interview questions and answers to prepare you

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Where can you learn about operations with numbers? Choices:  A: math book B: phonebook C: statistic D: music school E: office<n><n>### Response:		<n>**C: Statistic**<n><n>The statement of a quantitative research problem is called the “statistic statement” by many. The population is then divided up into groups. For example, a study of the prevalence of obesity may be limited to men and women between the ages of 15 to 30. This defines the population from which a sample will be drawn. A list containing all the names of those in the population would be a “statistic.”<n><n>### Additional Information:<n>**Statisticians**<n>*A statistician is a person who analyzes, summarizes, interprets, and reports information from a survey.**<n><n>### [Exploration](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1U7J6bIhRd50VKqJN8BVV_vM0QQd-bZqyYG-C6JCY2_2g/edit?usp=sharing) :<n>- [Math](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/excel/excel-2016-get-started)<n>- [Statistics](https://www.statisticshowto.com/statistics/)<n>- [Graphs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bar_chart)<n>

Choices:  A: teach B: cost money C: do work D: be productive E: help people<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### In a nutshell...<n>The office has: <n><n>* A total of 10 computers. <n>* The cubicles that have at least two computers total to 4 of the cubicles. <n>* Each employee has one computer in their cubicle. <n>* Each cubicle has 4 computers in total.<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>Dr. Banks has 64 chairs for his patients to sit in. Twenty two percent of them have the arm rests broken off.  He takes 16 of his chairs and trades them with another dentist office to get 80 new chairs. All the chairs end up with broken arm rests again. How many chairs does he have now?<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### In a Nutshell...<n><n>Dr. Batch trades in 16 chairs, getting 66 new ones with broken arm rests. After trading, he has  16 broken arm rest/new chairs (16 new chairs - (16/16 (broken arm rests) times  66 (total chairs))<n><n>#### The Deets...<n>Let's start by explaining what we're given in more detail. This will help us break down what is going on and determine what we need to know.<n><n>* Dr. Batch has 64 chains, 22% which have broken arm rests.<n>* Dr. Banks swaps in 16 chains (from the 64 total) in return for 66 new chairs.<n>* The chairs have broken arm rests, so he gets 66 new chains with broken armrests instead. <n>* The value of all chairs now = 66 new chiains with broken armrests + (16 new chair - (16/22 (chairs without arm rests) times 66 (chairs))<n><n>Therefore, his total number of chairs is = 16 (new chairs) - 22 (number of broken arm rests new chairs) = 66 new chair with broken arm rests + 16 broken arm rests new chair.<n><n>### Task<n>In a city there is a group of n homes arranged in a ring with an extra space. Each home is represented as

The program is to return the commas as if they were in a string and space them out. Commas should be replaced with the following: ( "," )<n><n>### Name of the file to be used: stringcommaprogram.py<n>Example:<n><n>1.Name( string )<n>2.Comma( string )<n>3.Name( string ) + "," + Comma( string )<n><n>Example  #2: Input:  My name is john, you?<n>Output:  My name is John, you?<n><n>### Example 3:<n>Input:  There was a young lady from Nome who came with a name that was very long and odd.<n><n>Output:  There was a Young Lady from Nome who came With a name that was very Long and Odd.<n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n>name = raw_input.input("My name is ") #string from the user without space between 'My name is'and ''.<n>string = name  + ','.join(name.split()) #create strings. For example:  ['Paul','John']<n>print string #display the output of the name and lastname in one statement. If we use a = and a.join we will still be able to use the name and last name in different statements later. Example:'Paul, John '<n><n>lastname = name.split()[0] #extract the first part after the split() command in our example: ['Paul','John'] from the string we are about to print. <n>print ','.join(lastname) #print all our examples in one line'Paul, John'by joining the strings together.<n><n>lastname = lastname[:3] #extract the substring from the first 3 characters<n>print lastname #output'Paul '<n><n>lastnamex = lastname[:3].split()<n>print lastnamex #output Paul, with comma, and 'x' (x doesn't seem to work but can be ',' or '.')<n><n>splitname = name.split('/')<n><n>print splitname[1] #we see  'john'<n><n>string

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:The human looked down longingly as he sat in the orbiting space station, what did he miss? Choices:  A: nearest house B: workplace C: surface of earth D: office block E: his feet<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Input: The human looked down longingly […] what did he miss? […] nearest house. […]A<n><n>### Instructions for each Response:<n>Please respond to the below Question in a way that is appropriate to your role and work.<n><n>This is the first example where this feature makes its presence in the instruction. In this example, the instruction is to produce a piece of work, whereas in later examples, the task is to perform a mathematical calculation.<n><n>### Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>In this multiple choice question, which the user can select from.<n><n>### A: Nearest house<n>In the response, the question asks us to “Please respond to the below question”. This would seem like an odd request. Usually a question is a sequence of words requesting a response, e.g., “What’s your favorite color?” or “Which of these four is the answer”.<n><n>To understand this more, we can compare it to “What’s your response to the question below?” and “Which of these is the answer?”.<n><n>The first version, “Which of these [list] is the answer?”, seems to be like a valid piece of instruction. However, this is no longer valid in the context where the feature is described. The original description of the format of the instructions makes them too narrow for this purpose.<n><n>Conversely, the format “Which of these” would be invalid for an instruction describing a mathematical calculation or similar.<n><n>Therefore, the “Please respond to the question below” must be the correct syntax for textual instructions.<n><n>### B: Workplace<n>It could be a case where this question is used as a distraction. If the user selects B, then they will be asked to answer a question. However, this question would be a request for a piece of work, and therefore a distraction, which makes it likely that the distraction is used to slow down the solving process.<n><n>### C: Surface of earth<n>This answer seems to be used as an example of something to ask for that is not possible. However, we know that the questions used as distractions are questions within the instruction itself.<n><n>### D: Office block<n>See B<n><n>### E: his feet<n>See B<n><n>#### Examples of other answers
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Long term consumption of beer can lead to all sorts of problems, it can be quite what? It is a capital vowel and is "E", "I", "N", "O", or "U"<n>2. It is a lowercase vowel and is "e", "i", "n", "o", or "u"<n><n>If the second letter in your name isn't "E", "I" "N", "O" or "U" or a digit, then it is not a vowel.<n><n>### Excessive<n><n>### What is excessive?<n><n>### Answer the "Is it excessive" question given below.<n><n>### What will the variable n be?<n><n>### What does n equal?<n><n>### Output?<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>##

Choices:  A: redemption B: isolation C: absolution D: great relief E: feel better<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the answer is A, then the sentence should be changed to read "If I have a forgiveness of attitude toward someone, what does they receive?" Because forgiveness is an action that the person makes not a state of being.<n><n>### Input:"It's sooo frustrating when you're right at a stage in development where you know what you're doing and life is going along fine like it always has and then the rug gets pulled out from under you." How should the sentence be revised? Choices: <n><n>A: Delete the word "development" <n><n>B: Delete the word "rug"<n><n>C: Change "frustrating" to "devastating"<n><n>D: Change "under you" to "around you"<n><n>E: Change "right" to "just"<n><n><n>### Response : If the answer is D, then the sentence should read<n>The rug gets pulled out from right under you. It should read that because "rugs" are under "floors" and because "right" is an adjective.<n><n>###  Input:"I love getting up in the morning not knowing what to expect out in the yard, but in the afternoon finding a great shot."  How should the sentence be changed?<n><n>Choices: <n><n>	A: Delete sentence starting with "I love getting up"<n><n>	B: Delete the word  "but"<n><n>	C: Delete the word "great"<n><n>	D: Combine the sentence starting with "I loving getting up... " and the rest <n>of the sentence so instead of reading<n>"I love getting up in morning not knowing what to expecting out in the yard,..." it <n>will read "I love getting up in  the morning not knowing what or expecting out<n>in the yard, but in afternoon finding out a great shot."<n><n>### Review:  The above input and response is grammatically incorrect. So, the solution for this instruction is to rewrite the sentence so that it reads,<n>The rug gets pulled from under you. It should state that because "floors" are above "rugs" and because "right under you" is an adverb.<n><n>### Problem 2<n>Below is an instruction that describes requesting a task. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Rumors of roving bands of monsters killing people could lead to what? Choices:  A: panic B: getting in trouble C: mass hysteria D: go to prison E: murder<n><n>### Response:		A.<n>

For example, if you do not have a car, you can still go places if you take a bus.<n><n>### Input A:  How would something look if you cannot use your hands<n><n>### Response A:<n>A is the response because you can still see things in places where you cannot use your sight.<n><n>###Input B:  How would something smell if it were invisible?<n><n>###Response B:<n>B is the response because it is still there whether you can smell it or not. An invisible item can still go away or become something else.<n><n>###Answer B:<n>B is not the answer because an invisible item can still go somewhere whether you can smell something or not. An invisible thing can stay visible and you can smell it.<n><n>###Response C:<n>C is the response because the answer to a question is still not the same thing the question was asking. Example, if you look for a person who only weighs 6 pounds, but cannot find them because they are invisible, can you still look for them because you can still ask the question?<n><n>###Answer C:<n>C is not the answer because you can still try to find the person who only weigh 6 pounds no matter what is their vision.<n><n>### D<n>Because it is not the same as something is not needed. D would be the answer<n><n>### E<n><n>D is the answer<n><n>## #Ask a question

If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:What is an way for people to meet with each other? Choices:  A: believe in god B: pay bills C: group together D: enjoy themselves E: face each other<n><n>### Response:		<n>What is an good way to meet people of interest to you? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:The banjo finds it's history in the Caribbean, but it's probably most famous where? Choices:  A: music shop B: music store C: jug band D: united states E: among nice people<n><n>### Response:		Music Store<n><n>### Incomplete Request:Demonstration:<n>* Input:The banjo find it's history in Spain, but it's best known where? Choices: A: music shop B music store C: jug bar D: United States E other countries<n><n>### Request:Tell how and where the banjo is best known.<n><n>### Response 1:The banjo became famous in United States during the first half of 20th century.<n><n>### Request 2:Tell how and when the banjo was first made.<n><n>###Response 3:The banjo is said to have been made first by Africa slaves but no dates were written down.<n><n>### Inputs: 50 of 120 people polled said a penguin's birthday was a holiday in their country, 30 of 90 people polled said their penguin was a saint, 120 people said that the weather was warmer in their country in the summer, 90 people said that it got dark earlier in their country in the winter, 150 people polled said that their penguins language was used, and 60 people polled said they have a holiday that honors their penguin.<n>What nationalities can tell us more about their penguin?<n>A. United States, Ireland, and Scotland<n>B. Scotland, Ireland,and United States<n>C. Ireland, Scotland, and United States<n>D. Ireland,Scotland, and United States<n><n>### Response A:<n>Penguins from the United States, Scotland, and Ireland share a birthday holiday. Penguins from Scotland, Ireland, and United States share a weather holiday. Penguin from the United States, Ireland, Scotland share a penguins language holiday.<n><n>###Request A: Tell what other festivals or celebrations nationalities have?<n><n>### Response B: The United States, Ireland, or Scotland share a holiday.<n><n>* Response B: The United Stated, Ireland, and Scotland share a birthday holidays, penguin's language holiday, and a weather holiday.<n><n><n>### Request B:Tell what other festivals or holidays that your penguin share with others.<n><n>###Inputs:

Write VBA that takes a start column address and a number of column address of the data it returns.<n>#<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write your response in a Word Document.<n>### Input:<n>- 5 people are waiting in the DMV<n>- there are 5 counters<n>- each counter has 5 employees<n>- each employee is able to process 4 people a day<n>- each person is willing to wait up to 2 hours if it shortens total time<n>- the computer in the DMV has a flaw, so the computer is unable to get more than 4 people through in an hour<n><n>### Demostration:<n>- Counter 1 is processing Counter 2 can process<n>- Counter 2 is processing Counter 1 can process<n>- Couter 3 is processing Counter 4 can process<n>etc<n><n>### Response (Write your Word Document):<n>### Input:Create a function that takes input from the user.  Your function should be formatted such that the correct value is returned if the input is a number (if no number is typed, your function should print “invalid input”), the correct value is returned of the input is within a list of known strings, the correct value is returned and the program prints “invalid input” is the input is not in the above list, and the correct value is returned when the input is anything else (with a message that displays “unknown input”).<n><n>### Demos:<n>The input for the unknown input type is 7.<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>def input(input_string):<n>    if input_string.isnum():<n>        return int(input_string)<n>```<n>### Instrucction: Write a recursive function that takes an integer array and returns true or false to indicate if that array can be obtained by rotating the first number of the array so it becomes the last, then rotating the last number so it becomes the first. You may pass the function an array of size 0, and if you receive an array of size 1 or less, the function should return false. Home Depot and Kitchen are synonyms since floors can be placed on kitchen.<n><n>### Input:: The girl asked her mother to buy her a pair of shoes.  The girl’s choice was between 1) shoes blue, 2) shoes purple, 3) shoes green (not purple and green), 4) shoes purple (not green). Which shoes did the mother buy her?<n>Answer: Choices:  blue shoes<n><n>### Input A:  a girl asked her mother to choose a pair  her choice was between 1 and 2  and her mother chose 2  The second question she asked about is 3 which was shoes blue not green<n><n>### Response A:<n>The girl asked her mother to pick a pair of shoes from a total of 5 shoes. Her choice was either blue shoes or purple shoes. So, based on the choices and the outcome, her mother was wrong.<n><n>###  Input B:  A: the man asked the salesman where to find some shoes  B: the man asked the the salesman  where he could find some shoes  C: the man asked the where to find some shoose  D: the man asked the  where can he find some shoes   B is the best answer<n><n>### Response B:<n>The man asked "Where can I find some shoes."<n><n>### Input C:  The man asked the woman where to find shoes<n><n>## Input:  A: the woman asked her friend if she could play basketball  B: the woman asked her friends if she could play basketball today<n><n>### Response C:  C is correct because of the placement of the comma it can refer to all of the woman's friends<n>

He didn't heave anything to put it on, and he lacked the what to balance it? Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choose E: breaking.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>From paragraph 1: <n><n>>  "It didn't matter. He didn't heave​ anything to put it on." The man did not have any hands for holding things, or any way to balance the cup. He did not have any means to lift anything to give to the table. <n><n>### Feedback:<n>If this task is too difficult, you can ask for feedback. How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Where do you put your grapes just before checking out? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery cart C: super market D: fruit basket E: fruit market<n><n>### Response:		<n>### If the fruit market is just for grapes, put the grapes in the fruit market.<n>### When that's clear, put the grapese in the super market.<n>### If they're not just for grapes put them in the fruit market. If the fruit market is for grapes only (or fruit that contains grapes), put the grapes and the other fruit there.<n><n>The first two responses above are wrong, because I am being asked to follow a condition, not perform a task. Whenever that happens, that is always the wrong response.<n>### Input: Find as many birds as you can in this picture. There's a bird in the top left corner, there's another bird near that in the top right corner, and there's a bird near the top center.<n>### Response: I found three birds. A bird near the top. A bird in top right, and a bird in the top.<n><n>The last 3 responses are correct because you have actually been asked to complete a task. The only reason to provide a response is if your response completes the task or clarifies the task. The task is to find birds, hence the three birds.<n>The first two responses are not acceptable because they are not correct responses. These responses follow the condition, not the task.<n><n>### Input A man who was given four apples gave each of his two children one.  How many apples did they receive?<n>Response 1:<n>I gave each of my children one apple. Apples: 1, Number of apples:0.<n><n>Reason, I am answering condition and not the task. <n><n>Response 2:I split the apples equal so the children each get two and now I don't have any left. <n><n>Reason, If you choose to be mean, and give the children each 2 of the apples, in the process I give myself 0; the question has been answered.<n><n>Response 3:I don't know why, I just can't imagine people having too many apples.<n><n>Reason: I am answering a question about apples, so that is why I can't imagine people have enough apples. <n><n>### Input<n>A teacher wanted to give each of her students an apple. She had enough for each student if each student

Answer the question in the picture below.<n><n>### Paint by Numbers Instructions:<n>Input: This painting is 11 inches by 12 feet long. You have to work with a 6 inch painting that contains one-sixth of everything in the 12 feet painting, but also contains everything that has to be in the 12 foot painting.<n>Answer: 12 inches by 4 feet long<n><n>Input: This painting has three parts, 3 inches by 15 inches, 2 inches by 7 inches, and 1 inch by 3 inches, but only one of each of those parts is given. Choose a shape to put as one of the two other parts. (One 6 inch piece is given.)<n>Answer: Two triangles with each triangle being 1 inch by.5 inches<n><n>### Instruption:Write the program code that fulfills the request.<n><n>Write a program that asks for 3 numbers from a user. You will have to subtract a second number from the first one. When you subtract two different numbers or two equal numbers, your final number must always be the smaller one. If you do not find any number that can be subtracted from the first without causing the second to be greater than the first, exit the program.<n><n>### Example: <n><n>If the user inputs 13, 7 and 19 then the output should be 6.<n>Otherwise. The program should give them a message that they need to enter numbers that you can subtract to get the smallest number.<n><n>### Input <n><n>Three numbers less than 100<n><n>Output<n><n>The smallest number<n><n>### Example 2<n><n>If the user enters 15, 7 and 2, the output will be 5.<n><n>### Output<n><n>Smallest Number<n><n>### Example three<n><n>If the user input 12, 7, 21 and 4, the output should be 11.<n><n>If the user is to be subtracted from each number from the first without causing that the second to be greater, the output should be negative.<n>

Incomplete or incorrect responses will be returned.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Three of the following words are misspelled: Incorrect: A)  chanage, B)  chanj, C)  chainge, D)  chanjing, E)  chnage<n><n>### Response<n><n>E)  chnage

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:What would you do if you want to be able to earn money? Choices:  A: apply for job B: stand in line C: take care of proposals D: pass course E: play the lottery<n><n>### Response:		<n>Let's figure the one that is the correct answer for the problem below:<n>>A: apply for job<n>### Explanation:<n>When we are applying for the job, we have to prepare our CV/resume and make the presentation to the company that we are working with.<n><n>---<n>### Solution (a solution has more than just an answer):<n><n>1)  Create the file<n><n>2)  Open up the file<n><n>3)  Insert a blank line<n><n>4)  Start writing up your program<n><n>5)  Write up a header<n><n>  - Make sure the header follows the coding standards of your school, company, or team<n><n>  - Indent your code so it's easier to read<n><n>6)  Make your functions and procedures<n><n>  - If your function or procedure has a return value, make sure you use var myVariable = 0; to clear the return value<n><n>  - Give a descriptive name to your functions and procedures -- like "Function to add up 3 numbers"<n><n>  - Create nested functions and procedures if needed<n><n>  - Make the variables and constants in your functions and procedures available to the code that calls them (for example, make sure the function foo(3) can access the constant BAR)<n><n>  - Do not return error messages to the main code<n><n>  - Write your comments to explain why and how the function or procedure is being utilized<n><n>7)  Create variables and constants that are used in your functions and procedures<n>8)  Write code that uses the functions and procedures that you've written<n><n>### Reference:<n>1. Choices:  A: wasteland B: ocean C: desert D: parking lot E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### First attempt: The city's community garden is a parking lot<n>#### Second attempt: The city'll have to give the community garden back to the city <n>#### Third attempt: The city'd better give the community garden back<n>#### Fourth attempt: Let's give the community garden back before they do <n>#### Fifth attempt: That damn community garden needs to be removed<n>#### Sixth attempt: The city needs to remove the community garden<n>#### Seventh attempt: Let's hope the community garden is removed<n><n>### Input2:Choose either "The community garden needs to be renewed." or "We need to replant the community garden.".<n>Answer:"The community garden needs to renewed."<n><n>### Instructions: Write a code segment, complete this task.<n>Input: 19 is a prime number. What is the third number that ends with "3"? Choices: A: 31 B: 32 C: 223 D: 423 <n><n>### Input 2: "Three"<n><n>### Response A<n><n>```csharp<n>if (num == 9)<n>{<n>   Console.Write("3");<n>}<n>else<n>{<n>    if ((num % 3!= 0) && (num%3 == 1))<n>    {<n>        Console.Write("4");<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Response B<n><n>```csharp  <n>if ((num < 3) || (((num%3==0) && num%5!=3) || ((num%3 ==1) && num%5==1)))<n>{<n>    Console.Write("2");<n>}<n>else if(num%3==2)<n>{<n>    Console,Write("2");<n><n>}<n>else if(( ( ( ( ( num%3!=0) || (num%3 ==1))&&(num%5!=2) ) && (num%5!=1))  && (num%5!=3))) {<n><n>    //<n>    // "3"<n>    Console.Write( "3" );<n><n>}<n>else<n> {<n>    Console.Write ( "3" );<n>}<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a bee gathering pollen? Choices:  A: united states B: sky C: court D: field of flowers E: orchard<n><n>### Response:		Answer B, Sky<n><n>### Reasoning:Orchards are found around cities where they can be farmed. Also, they are always open, therefore they are not found in closed areas which is an important quality of a bee gathering place.<n><n>### Input Answer:E<n><n>### Reporter:Write a sentence that appropriately answers the question.<n><n>## Input:What is a 6-letter word that contains the 4 letters in the word "hospital"?<n>## Response:Health<n><n>## Reporter:Write a response that appropriately responds to the question.<n>## Instruction:What word begins with H and is only 5 letters long?<n>

Choices:  A: kitchen cupboard B: pantry C: grocery store D: pantry E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		 A: kitchen<n><n>### Explain:  It would be bad if my ingredients went bad. Since they are highly visible on my cupboard, I could see them all the time.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: I have a jar of fruit preserve  If I start with 2 bottles of the same preserve, the third bottle has one more cap on top than the second bottle.  I have exactly two times as many bottles of the same taste as the number of bottles of the same flavor. How many bottles of the preserve do I have?<n><n>### Answers<n><n>A. 4<n><n>B. 7<n><n>C. 14<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>Let's use the 2x as an equation for number of bottles. You have 1 more bottle on your second preserve, but you also have twice as many, so you would only need 4 caps. Then you have twice as many bottles but only one extra cap from your second preserve. This means you need 4 bottles.<n><n>### Question:In which country did the 2010 Winter Olympics take place?<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>A. _____<n><n>B. _____<n><n>C. _____<n><n>D. _____<n><n>### Exclusion method:<n><n>* Excluded Countries: Canada<n>* No Countries That Start with "A": Azerbaijan, Algeria, Argentina, Andorra, Angola<n>* No Capital Cities<n>* Countries that start with B: Botswana, Benin, Bermuda, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Burkina Faso, Bhutan<n>* Countries that Starts with C: Cameroon, Chad, Cayman Islands<n><n>### Final Answer: Canada<n><n>### Excluded Solutions:<n><n>B. United States<n><n>C. Japan

How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:If you want to make a big splash in a river with a rock, from where should you throw it? Choices:  A: mountains countryside B: ground C: bridge D: mountain range E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A)<n>Throw it from the mountain range as river water flow is usually slow in mountain ranges and you will make minimum splash (<0.1in)<n><n>#### B):<n>Throw it from ground, because the splash will be greater than 0.1 due to high water velocity flowing at large volumes per hour.<n><n>#### C):<n>Throw it from bridge, less surface contact with the river water and you will also not create much splash but you might make the splash heard faraway(sound travels fast in air)<n><n>#### D):<n>Throw it from the mountains countryside, water will flow fast in the mountains in river basin due to inclined surfaces which forces water to cover great distances with high velocity(a lot of splash may result)<n><n>#### E):<n>Throw it from surface of earth as nothing has effect on it and will make highest splash (<1in)<n>

For a train station, a total of 66,116 tickets are sold each day. For a cathedral, a total of 162,675 tickets are sold each week. For a metro station, a total of  208,242 tickets are sold each month. For a fairgrounds, a total of 49,260 tickets are sold each year.For an amusement park, a total of 216,200 tickets are sold per month. Each cathedral sells more tickets than each station. The park sells the least number of tickets per year.<n><n>

In fact, they may have more than one electric in their home.<n><n>### Input :What are 2 uses of a fan that do not relate to the electric fan that is used at home?<n><n>### Response :There are two uses of a computer. A use of a computer is a machine. A use of a is a box with keys.(sorry the box with keys is to make the reader understand that a computer is a box with keys). Use of a computer. Another use of a computer is for typing. Use of another computer.<n><n>### A use :<n>An object to do.<n><n>### An example Use:<n>My bicycle needs an oil change.<n>### More examples:<n>- My watch needs a new battery.<n>- My car needs a new engine.<n>- My car uses oil.<n>- My car has a carburetor.<n>- My car is in a mechanic garage.<n><n>### Not an example:<n>a use: A mechanic garage. A use: The engine needs to be repaired.<n><n>### The bicycle needs an is. The purpose of this sentence is _________<n><n>### The purpose: The purpose of this sentence needs an oil change.(The purpose of this sentence)<n><n>### The use of: the purpose of this sentence is to make the reader remember that the sentence needs an oil change. (The purpose of this sentence.)<n><n>### Is an abbreviation for:<n><n>### Is (word) is a word that means the same as.<n><n>### For example: use = for (word) to do.<n><n>1. <n>### The word (word ) needs to be used the same as in (sentence ). The purpose of this sentence : To have the reader remember that the purpose of this sentence means to do the same words as the sentence is to use<n>### The is abbreviation : The (name ) is a name that means the same as.<n><n>### The is (word ) is a name is the word that needs to be used.<n>### to make the reader remember if that the is abbreviation is to use the word the same as the name.<n><n>### (name) The name, (

Choices:  A: nailed B: carved C: polished D: eat cake E: petrify<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>What does a "Grammaticality" sentence example test?<n>### Response A: Grammaticality sentence example is to test grammar.<n>### Response B: A sentence that can be grammatically corrected would be a grammar example.<n>### Response C: The sentence is grammatical, without any errors.<n>### Response D: 61% of grammar is correct.<n>### Response E: Grammar tests sentences for errors.<n><n>### Input.<n>To increase by 10% the original cost of a product, what percent of original cost remains?<n>### Response: The answer would be.<n>### Input<n>To increase by 20% the original cost, how many cents per unit?<n>##Response:<n>### Input<n>In the first step of the process, the total cost would be $5.00.<n>### Response A.<n>Based on a previous total cost of $5.00 the total cost would increase by 50%.<n>### Response B.<n>There should be a response but when you take the total cost and multiply it by.50, the total cost will become $6.25.<n><n>### Response B<n>In the first step, the total cost would increase. ## In the second step, the total cost after doubling would be ten times.<n>### Response J<n>If you increase the total cost by a 60% you will have a total cost of $3.50.<n><n>### Output<n>To increase by 8%, what percent of original cost?<n>### Output A.<n>The percent increase would be.08 to get a percent.<n>### Output B.<n>If the original cost is 75, then.<n>### Output C.<n>The total cost would be.075 to multiply the cost increase times the percentage.<n>### Output D<n>If you increase your total cost by a 95%, then the total cost increase is $5.00 for a total cost of $10.00.<n><n>## Solution<n>Answer A - to increase a total cost by a specific amount, multiply that by a percent.<n><n>Answer B - The answer is one-fourth of the original cost.<n><n>Answer C - No, if you decrease the answer, it'll say 1-1/

Choices:  A: towed B: accidents C: driving D: getting tired E: ticket<n><n>### Response:		<n>> The answer that I choose would be B: accidents. I think this answer is the most accurate and most realistic as there are many reasons why one's car would be towed such as the car is parked on a street during a street fair. If one's car was parked during a street fair, there are usually notices on the ground or posted on the street pole next to the ticket you get to remind one to move their car once the event ends as it is blocking the view of other customers who want to walk down the line and see everything that the shop has to offer. Another reason would be that the car's parking time is expired and was not moved back to the parking space after the time limit. It was probably because the driver forgot or forgot to get the car back to its parking spot before the time limit is reached. I feel this answer is the answer that makes the most sense among the others as all of the others seem too extreme and in this case it wouldn't be fair enough for a car to be towed, unless the car's parker was a chronic forgetter and kept on leaving his/her car parked in the same place, causing the car to be towed numerous times, and the only solution now is to get a new car because you can't even count on your old one now anymore.<n><n>### Input:[The shadows get 1543 inches at 7:30.] Which time is that?<n><n>### Response:[7:30]<n><n>### Inputs:[Sunrise at 6:00.
