He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:What do people in the same family often share? Choices:  A: brown hair B: names C: two eyes D: will E: brains<n><n>### Response:		What do people in the same families likely? Choices:  C:  Two eyes<n>

How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon. Write a response.<n><n>### Response-driven instruction:Write a response to the task below.  <n>```<n>I have found a place that sells panties at an amazing price! You'll have to drive a little ways to get there, though.<n>```<n><n>### Instruct student to explain why the word place is incorrect:  <n>The correct word is place and place should never be preceded by a.  <n><n>The correct term is a place.  <n><n>There are four rules for adjectives. These rules determine the position of adjectives with in a sentence.<n><n>1. Adjectives always precede the noun they modify (The man in the red shirt).  <n>2. They always follow the noun they modify except for determiners (a book, the, his, her) <n><n>3. Adjectives almost never modify adjectives (big beautiful blue eyes)<n><n>4. Adverbs sometimes precede the noun or adjective they modify. (She ran quickly through the muddy road.)  <n><n>### ESL-driven instruction:Respond to the task below.<n>Write a sentence or provide an example that includes the word big.<n>```<n>I always get an amazing massage from my masseuse.<n>```<n><n>Write a sentence or phrase that includes the word beautiful.<n>```<n>The city I live in is beautiful.<n>```<n><n># Question Link-<n><n>### Above Image-A man with a white ball is holding a stick underneath a bird with yellow feathers.<n><n>### Punjabi-Ravinder Singh<n><n>### English-Ancient Egypt

Choices:  A: driveway B: the event C: scrap heap D: parking garage E: repair shop<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### D: 04-23-2013<n>> There are 8 choices for this question.<n><n>## Solution<n>In order to accomplish the tasks, we must create a series of if, while, and for elseif structures.<n><n>With the first task, the question asks us to add our numbers together and subtract the difference and multiply by 5. So, we create a while loop to iterate through the numbers until there are no more subtraction operations. Inside of the while loop we create a variable "total", then append to it for each loop iteration. Since we need a break condition once we hit 90, we use "break".<n><n>After running this, I get 80 but the instructions said to subtract the numbers and get 90 as the result, thus, something else is probably wrong with my input.<n><n>After some thinking the while loop can iterate through the numbers without doing anything else. So, I had to rethink my while loop. <n>After some time I get 80 in response to the original instruction even though the result should have been 90. I did some research and found that I used variables "result" and "target" instead of "sum" and "total" respectively. Once I changed those to match I was able to arrive at my 90 expected result and was told to write a program to show me that sum and target were 1 less than each other.<n><n>With the second task, the instructions are pretty self explaneatory except for the subtraction operation which the statement says is not needed since the operations prior to and after are. So, I first create a variable to store the result and then in the if statement where the comparison between the number of Doebrman puppies and Schnauzers occurs I create a result variable to create. I then set it to a variable value of one less than the answer we expect in order for us to perform the subtraction.<n><n>With the rest of the task, I was required to modify the for statement which I think is necessary since it is not explicitly stated in the instructions. I simply put the statements inside the for statement and not inside of the if statement. I thought if I put it inside of the statement it would create an infinite loop because there would never be a time to check if the value of if statement "a" met the statement.<n><n>With my above modification for statement,

D: The killer was not a professional, they used a gun that would only shoot once and did not reload after. How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:A shower is an expected amenity when you reserve a what? Choices:  A: gy mnasiu m B: motel room C: seashore D: bath room E: locker room<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### How it works:<n>The word what looks like the English word want. But it is actually an object pronoun or, as some might say, the relative pronoun that.<n>The relative pronoun that is an object for what. It tells us what? That is in the sentence to make it complete.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>###  1. What is it?<n>**Answer:** It is an object pronoun. (a what)<n>###  2. A relative pronoun that tells you what?<n>**Answer: ** A what<n>###  3. A pronoun that that that that a pronoun that a pronoun a pronoun<n><n>### Input a sentence that could take the place of B. A. a. above.<n><n>### Response A. That is that. That is that.<n><n>### How that works:<n>Not quite. That is a relative pronoun in that sentence.<n>### Input 2: a dog is a relative pronoun.<n><n>### Input 3: In fact, all dogs are dogs.<n><n>### All dogs are what?<n><n>### Answer: a dogs.<n><n>## Explanation<n>### Input: A shower is an expected an amenity when you reserve an what? (a motel room, a shovel house, a seashore, a bath room, a locker room)<n><n>### Explanation:<n>A shower is expected amenity when you book an amenity.  An amenity means a room that have nice things such as a bathroom shower, refrigerator, TV, electric kettle, towels and soap etc.<n><n>### Answer to question: What is it?<n>It is a motel room. It is a motel room that you book.<n><n>### 3. Input 2: A what?<n><n>## Response: A what?<n>

To indicate a new line, use two dashes with spaces in between.<n>2. After new line use the same command as below (above)<n>```<n>- this is a first line<n>-<n>this is<n>a second-line<n>```<n>### How to create an "indented text block" in Markdown<n>1. Use one hash mark at the beginning of the text<n>2. Use the "fat arrow" (long dash) between the blocks<n>### What's the right way to include a URL in Markdown?<n>There are multiple ways to include the URL in Markdown.<n>1. 1. use angle brackets<n>2. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. Choices:  A: cook dinner B: eat C: go back to work D: make food E: get food<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>#include <iostream><n><n>using namespace std;<n><n>int main()        <n>{<n>    int choice = 0;<n><n>    char ch;<n>        do {<n>        cout<< "Choose your answer"<<" A:cook Dinner"<<" B: Eat at home"<<" C:Go back to work"<<" D:Make Dinner"<<endl;<n>        cin>>ch;<n>         choice = ch - 'A';<n><n>        case 1:(<n>           if (choice == 1)<n>            cout<<"Cook"<<endl;<n>           else if (choice == 2)<n>           cout<<"Eat "<<endl;<n>           cout << "go back to work?"<<endl;<n>           break;<n><n>         default:cout<<"Sorry wrong answer!"<<endl;<n>               }while (choice!= 0);    /* while loop to check for the exit condition */   <n><n>       return 0;<n>}<n>```<n><n><n><n>#####<n>

Choices:  A: from the sky B: map C: cross counties by car D: country E: michigan<n><n>### Response:		In this case, we have to look at 4 letters and the question is about the question itself, not about the correct number. To view a county highway as line we can do this by looking at a map. The map in this scenario is where we can see a line representing a highway and in our case that is the best choice.<n>

She only planted seed crops.<n><n>### Response<n>D<n><n># Task 2<n>### Instrucation<n>Write out a multi-step mathematical equation as described.<n><n>### Examples<n>A. Write a response that applies the relationship.<n>### Input solution 3<n><n>### Instructios 4<n>Solve with no solution box.<n><n>### Example<n><n>9/8 = 64/18 = 800/50 = 8000/400 = 20000/32 = 62500/25/625 000 = 25/62 000<n>### Solution<n>9/8=64/18=800/5=8000/8=25/62000=25/12646=50/11288=50/23142=3/232<n>### Input solution<n><n>### Input instructions 5<n><n>### Example (no solution box)<n><n>758-310 > 225<n><n>### Solution:<n><n><n>758 > 225 > 310 > 1 (since 758 is greater than 1) <n><n>### Input solution:<n><n>### Input solutions:<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>### Instruction

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:If you're betting with a shark, where are you likely playing? Choices:  A: aquarium B: mediterranean sea C: south pacific D: pool hall E: pacific ocean<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer A: Aquarium<n><n>#### Why?<n>Since the shark is probably a large predator, such as a Tiger Shark, a Great White, Lemon Shark, or maybe even a Hammerhead, he's looking to eat. This likely means that he is the big fish in the pond and the smaller creatures are prey. In other words, the shark is looking to feed and will probably be found in a location where he can find prey.<n><n>#### How do you know?<n>By the question's description of the shark, we can clearly see that the shark is aggressive enough to take on the other predators in the aquarium.<n><n>### Inputs: I live in the south-east. If  I go west, I'm going towards the west coast. If  I go north, I'm going toward the coast in the north.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer D:  Pacific Ocean<n><n>#### Why? <n>Based on the question, we can assume that the direction of travel is only relative to the person and that if someone were to be looking down from the clouds, or even, heaven's no! The stars, they would see a line coming from where the person started, through the destination. This would indicate movement north east. By using this method, the only possible answer is D, since the Pacific Ocean is always moving north east from anywhere in the Northern Hemisphere.<n>#### How Do you know? <n>By knowing that the question does not assume a north-south alignment, we could eliminate all of the other possible directions based on the question.<n> <n>### Input:  The speed of sound is about 787 miles per hour. How often is 1000 miles in a minute? Choices: A: 16666 times B: 16676 times C: 16696 times D: 16706 times<n><n>#### A) If<n><n>##### Given:<n>The speed of sound is about  786 mph<n><n>##### If<n><n>##### then<n>The speed of sound divided by 786 = The speed of sound x 787 mph / 786 mph =  1061.3 miles in one minute<n><n>##### How?<n>* By div

Choices:  A: bathroom B: walkway C: use D: hair salon E: drawer<n><n>### Response:		Use<n><n>###  [View Solutions](https://lucbebronx.github.io/golangs-multiple-choice-problems/solutions/)<n><n>### 1/4.<n>```<n>package main<n><n>import (<n>    "fmt"<n>    "reflect"<n>)<n><n>var _ = fmt.Errorf<n>var _ = reflect.Equal<n>var _ = reflect2.Equal<n><n>func main() {<n>    input := []float{4, -18, 1, 6,-2}<n>    response := -8<n><n>    for _, element:  = range input {<n>        response = response + element<n>    }<n>    fmt.Printf("The sum is: ", response)<n>}<n>```<n>input:[]float{4, -20, 38, 45, 5}<n>response:-9<n><n>### 2/4.<n>```go<n>package Main<n><n>import (<n>//"unsafe"<n>    "fmt"	<n>//"math"<n>	"math"<n>//"strconv"<n>//"bufio"<n>//"bytes"<n>//"regexp"<n><n>)<n><n>var x *int64<n>var y *int64<n><n>//y = x + 2<n>func init() {<n>	x = new(int64)<n>	*x = 5<n>	y = x<n>}<n>print(x)<n><n>//fmt.Println(*y)<n><n>func test() (res *int64) {<n>	res = y<n><n>	fmt.Println(res)<n><n>	return res<n>}<n><n>func main()<n>{<n><n>	value := test()<n><n>	fmt.Fprint(os.Stdout,value)<n><n>}<n>```<n><n>output:<n><n><b>main.go:48:2: undefined: print</b><n><n><b>error: unexpected EOF while scanning string literal</b><n><n>output:<n>5<n>-12<n><n>### 3/4.<n>### 4/4.<n>##<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Changing society using a violent conflict is know as a what? Choices:  A: action B: demonstration C: understanding D: vote E: revolution<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### A: action<n><n>### Inputs:Which of the following would be a good example of positive action taken to make change in our culture? Choices:   <n>> A: Write a poem about how you feel<n>> B: Write a blog<n>> C: Give money to a charity<n>> D: Protest publicly against a cause<n>> E: Call to action to everyone in your network<n><n>### A is a good example of action because it requires direct engagement and focus on the problem you are trying to solve. For example you might write a poem about how you personally feel about the current culture surrounding this issue.<n><n>### B is also action. It may not require as much personal direct engagement, but it still takes the person behind it to share the thoughts on the issue they feel strongly about. For example this could be done through a blog.<n><n>### C is an example of direct monetary action. The donation of money is one of the oldest, most respected forms of action in our society. This action does not require personal engagement, and does not require a public statement through an act of protest. Instead through a direct donation, you are directly supporting a cause.<n><n>### D is an example of action. It is the form of action most historically seen as the only effective way of impacting a society through positive action. Protesting is, by definition, active, and takes an effort to be effective.<n><n>### E is perhaps the worst choice, in the question it is suggested that an action taken by someone who is already connected to others online, or through a digital network could lead to a more change. To say that an action can be done, requires the presence of that action online or on social media.<n><n>### The example provided, the call to action where people are asked to make statements about a hot button issue or event and put them online, is the worst example of action.<n><n>### Input A:Which of the previous answers is the best action of the following? Choices:<n><n>### B: Write a poem about homeless people<n><n>### A does not require action to be effective. Writing a poem implies that you are using your voice by speaking directly to what you feel the issue surrounding homeless people is. However while this is an example of action, it doesn't require any action by the writer in doing so. Because

Dr. Wexler: "What I hear about her work on gamma ray photons is really fascinating.  I think she makes a strong contribution to our knowledge of the world."   Dr. Park: "I have to disagree with you.  In my opinion, her work on alpha ray photons has more of an impact."   If you think Dr. Wexler is correct, choose A.  If you think Dr. Park is correct, choose B.  If you think both are correct, choose C.  If you think neither is correct, choose D.<n><n>### Response:(B)<n>### Input:  John has an important interview. If John gets the job he has been dreaming about, he will have a lot more responsibility.  Which would he find more valuable:  A: the benefits of his job,  B: his family life, or C: a steady paycheck?  Choices:  A,B, or C<n><n>### Response:: C<n><n><n><n><n>### Input:)I think the answer choice is (A) is correct<n><n>### Response:)Because John's answer to the most valuable thing in the world in this situation is an important job. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Lizards need the sun's heat to regulate their body temperature, this is why you'll see them still on what? Choices:  A: bushes B: dessert C: books D: heat lamps E: rocks<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**(C)** Books<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: Two people play a game of Monopoly. At the onset of the game, one person owns 4 houses, the other person owns 3 houses and 2 hotels. What is the total value of houses owned by both people in the end of the game?<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>3<n><n><n>### Input <n><n>Input: Three people play a game of monopoly.  At the onset, one person owes the other $75, while the two other players owe $100 and $500 to each other respectively.  The person who owes $500 pays off the two other players simultaneously, and pays off the other person one month later. How much money does the person owed $75 have in total at the end of the game.<n>### Response<n>### Input<n>Input: Five people play a game of tic-tac-toe, on the first square, a player A wins a match in a total of 19 moves and 9 moves later, a player B also wins. How many times did it take all six players to win a match?<n><n>### Demmersion<n><n>The 1st player A wins in 19 moves.<n>The 2nd player B wins in 9 moves.<n>As the first player A beat B, it does not impact any players moves, making this second 9 moves count also.<n><n>### Response <n>### Input<n>The length of the baseball field has been halved, from 90 feet to 45 feet. A man runs around the diamond once every 15 seconds. What is the total time taken, now that the diamond has been halved?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Total time taken = half of one 15 seconds run around the diamond = 30 seconds<n><n>### Input and solution<n><n>The speed limit on a highway is reduced from 80 mph to 60 mph. If it takes 20% of the time to drive the exact same route as before, what is the speed limit of the 60MPH highway?<n>### Input<n>We were previously on the 80mph highway<n><n>Time needed to drive on 80mph =.20 <n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Where does a shadow usually appear? Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		The shadow usually appears on the surface of the moon.<n><n>### Input/Output:<n><n>**Input** :<n>![image](./images/input.png)<n><n>**Output** :<n>![image]("./images/output.png")<n><n>### Coding<n><n>### Pseudo code<n><n>*Define the input<n>Define the output<n>Define input/output relation<n>Define the rules for the task<n>Make use of rules to determine the output<n><n>```c<n>int inputSum();<n>int outputSum();<n>int num1;<n>int num2;<n><n>int inputSum(int num1,int num2){<n>	int sum;<n>	sum = num1+num2;<n>	return sum;<n>}<n><n>int outputSum(){<n>	int answer = (inputSum()+inputSum());<n>	return answer;<n>}<n><n>void defineRule(){<n>	num1 = (inputSum(num1,num2));<n>	num2 = (inputSum(sum));<n>}<n><n>```<n><n>### Notes<n><n>Write clear, self-explanatory and well formatted pseudo code. Use comments for your codes wherever necessary.<n><n><n>---<n>via: https://www.datacamp.com/community/tutorials/intro-to-logic-1-logic-gates<n>

If they didn't get to wave then they might've had a good view.<n><n>### Note - the question that the question is based on, is actually "How many people were there to watch the marching barand?"<n>

After that, her dog ate a quarter of the cake. How many pieces of cake are left? Choices:  Choices: A B C D E<n><n>### Response<n><n>* _E_. The cake is gone because when dogs eat cakes, it is hard to imagine any cake remains.<n><n>### Input B:<n><n>Sally counted 10 apples. Later, she picked 4 more from the tree. She ate half her apples. At that point, 6 apples were still in front of her.<n>How many apples are in front of her now?<n><n>### Response B<n><n>* _D_. Six apples only<n><n>### Input C:<n><n>At a conference, everyone can take notes on either yellow or green paper. There are at least 15 people present.  How many pieces of paper were needed for the pencil-users if there had to be at least one-third blue and at least one-fourth green?<n><n>### Solution C<n><n>Suppose the number of attendees at the conference is `a`, the number of people who took their notes on yellow paper is `b`, and the number who took their notes on green paper is `c`. Then, the number of pieces of paper used is calculated by:<n><n>```<n>    b * (1 + 3 / 4) + c * (4 / 4) = (a 5) / (a - 1) * (4 / 5) * ((b + c) - 1)<n>```<n><n>Since `a` is >= 15, this expression reduces to<n><n>```<n>    (a) * 4 / 5 * (b + c)  = ((a - 1) 4) * 5 * ((b + c)/(b + c - 1)<n><n>    (a) 40 / 5 * ((b * 4 + c) 4)<n><n>    (5a - 20) 40 * 4 = 200<n><n>    (10a - 80) 400<n><n>    a * b<n><n>    a<n><n>```<n><n>If one-third of

SIT DOWN<n><n>### Input<n>What is the largest number divisible by 8 and 9?<n><n>### Response<n><n>C. 56<n><n>### Question<n><n>What is the difference in the number of steps taken and the number of steps skipped when the first flight of stairs begins with 129 and the last flight of stairs ends with 141?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>32<n><n>### Question:<n><n>Daily temperature averages between -27° C and -9.4° C?<n><n>### Input response:<n><n>C. -12.8° C<n><n>### Question 1<n><n>Which number is 24% more than 2,200?<n><n>### Solution 1<n><n>C. 2,832<n><n>## Solution 2<n><n>```js<n>function solution(val, percent) {<n>   const total = parseInt(val * percent);<n>   const remainder = percent - (total/100);<n>   return parseInt(total) + remainder*100;<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Questions<n><n>What is the median of the given numbers?<n><n>```js<n>const myArray = [100, 2, 75];<n>console.log(myArray.sort().reduce((p, v) => (p + v))); // 100<n>```<n><n>Which of the following is the smallest?<n><n>Choices: C. -8%, A. -100%, B. -10000%, D. -500%<n><n>### Answer: C<n><n>What is the quotient of 42 and 12?<n><n>### Possible Answers for Solving:<n><n>First multiply divider by dividend to get a quotient for the next operation: 42 * 12 = 504<n><n>Second divide quotient by divider (remaining digits will be moved to power of tens) to get a final answer<n><n>12 / 12 = 1<n><n>### Question :<n><n>Which expression is not equivalent to 5 × 5?<n><n>A. 55<n>B. 25<n>C. 50<n>D. 5<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:A person notices popcorn, cotton candy on the grass, where is he likely? Choices:  A: soccer game B: fairgrounds C: movie theatre D: countryside E: state park<n><n>### Response:		<n>He is at the state park.<n><n>### Feedback:<n>The correct answer is E (state park). The person is at the state park, surrounded by food vendors at a food fair. Food vendors provide popcorn and cotton candy. The answer is not A (soccer field), not B (fairgrounds), not C (movie theater), and not D (countryside).<n><n>### InputA woman tells her friend that the total value of all of her shirts, dresses, jackets, and pants is $464. What is the sum of all the shirt sizes for all her shirts?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Feeback:The value of the woman's shirts is $216, the woman's pants are $113, the value of her dresses is $88, and the value of her jackets is $57. <n><n>### Input<n>If five times Amy’s salary is equal to the product of a number and a half, what’s Amy’s salary?<n>Answer: Amy is earning $100,000.<n><n>The salary = (5·(Number+Half))<n><n>So the answer will be = a*5<n><n>The number of the Amy will be (a/2+1) = a/2+1<n><n>Or<n><n>Amy’s Salary = (a x 5 ) = (a/(a+1) + 1

Choices:  A: feel pleasure B: look attractive C: compliments D: interesting experiences E: joy<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>- If we have a set of people, and a goal, we determine how many people fulfil the goal and how happy they are compared to other people.<n>- 18 girls: 180,180<n>- 5 girls: 220,140<n>- 3 boys: 330,50<n>- 1 man: 250,250<n>```<n><n>```<n>- We can then conclude that 22.22 boys are the happiest!<n>```<n><n>### Answer: 509<n><n>```<n>- If a boy's name starts with S, we know that 126/150 names have an S. 64% of the boys start with S.<n>- If the same were applied on girls, we can conclude that 322/360 girls start with S. 90% of the girls start with S.<n>```<n>### Input:Find a whole number N that is less than the sum of four whole numbers such that the product of N minus two divides N minus 4.<n><n>### Answer N=14, divisors are 1,2,3,6,7,14,21<n><n>### Output: If a letter stands for a vowel, how many times does it start a name? For example, 'Rachel' starts with 'R' and 'R' stands for a vowel.<n><n>Input: If a letter stands(representation) for a vowel, then how many times does it(letter) start a name? example: 'Rachel' and "R" is a vowel(which starts a name)<n><n>Input: E, J, U, O, I, A<n><n>```<n>- J: 9 times<n>- I: 8 times<n>- A: 7 times<n>- O: 7 times<n>```<n><n>## Bonus Question:How did you do in this? Choices:  A: house B: den C: family room D: wood E: floor<n><n>### Response:		<n>**A is correct; The best choice is a house, since no other options would work for a bean bag chair.**<n>\<n><n>### Demonsration:<n>Input: 7 times 6 times 5 times 4 is equal to 54. Two fewer than three times is equal to 7.  What number does this equation represent?<n><n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: If the number is three times something times another number, how many more times will the original number come?<n><n>Answer: times<n><n>Input: What is 2 more than three times 3?<n><n>Answer: Five<n><n>Input: Which of the following does not appear in the sequence 8, 15, 26, 39,?, 68, 81?<n><n>Answer: nine

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Where would you find isopropol alcohol and safety glasses? Choices:  A: pub B: restaurants C: in a park D: supermarket E: chemistry lab<n><n>### Response:		 A) pub<n><n>### Input/Response: If Tina is ¾ of the age of her mother, how many more years will it be before 9 more years than half the age of her mother’s current age?<n><n>### Response<n>A)28 years<n><n>### Answer:<n>```<n>// Solution:<n>function ageDiff() {<n>   this_age = this.age()<n>   mom_age = mom.age()<n>   diff = this_age * 3 / 4 - mom_age<n>   return diff<n>  }<n><n>  Tina.ageDiff()<n><n>Age: 65<n><n>AgeDiff: 0<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: jungle B: bamboo grove C: australian outback D: china E: child's book<n><n>### Response:		A jungle<n>A koala lives in a tree in a jungle.<n>The Aussie animals eat leaves off trees in jungles.<n>A child's book contains illustrations of a koala.<n>A koala lives on the mainland of Australia.<n>Australia is divided into six states, one is _Nortjern_ Territory, which refers to the northern most part of Australia, and one is South Australia. Australia's location is the same as the country China is positioned on. The closest continent to Australia is a country called Asia. An island is located in the Ocean that shares the same name as the country Australia. Some cities in Australia are Adelaide, Brisbane, Canberra, and Melbourne. The _panda_ is not native to Australia.<n><n>### Input<n>How many students are there in Dr. Sharpe's calculus class? Input the number of students that are in Dr. Sharpes class.<n><n>### Response<n>There are five answers, but only one is correct. Dr. Sharpe has 90 students in her class. In a letter she typed the 4 digit code 2090 to her boss for clarification that the answer is 90 students, but she needs to have a new password that works in the same way. The new code she received from the boss is 4 numbers of 4 digits each separated by dashes. The new code can be converted to a number by simply adding up the digits in any of the four spots in the number. For example 2090 can be converted to 5050+0000+5089+4499 or 9900+4089+5089. The only three possible conversions that are 4 digit numbers with no leftover digits are: 2090 = 6010, 2080 = 2080, and2040 = 8040.<n><n>### The letter contains a question<n>How many total fish in the lake if 0.6 of the fish are big catfish and the rest are perch and bass<n><n>Answer: 1090/88 = 12.2273<n>There are 12.23 big catfish in the lake

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:He finally found someone as ugly as him, knowing he wouldn't be the one sticking out was what? Choices:  A: gorgeous B: handsome C: pleasing D: glorious E: pretty beautiful<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>

In fact, the correct answer is that cat's eyes are white.<n><n><n>

Write it, then explain it briefly):<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The input describes a person going out to eat in the morning. Eating breakfast, the person orders eggs, toast and something to drink. Some of the things they can get to drink are coffee and wine. To be more specific, Brad can drink either coffee or wine or both. He cannot choose A, throw up.<n><n>In order to get a correct answer to this question he could first decide which things he is going to eat and then choose A-E. <n><n>Another strategy to get the right answer would be, pick one, the first thing that comes in your head that may be from the options and choose it. Once you choose a thing, continue reading the question till the end. If you get it right, great, but if not then start picking other options and choose them until you do.

Choices:  A: damage B: cloud mind C: lower i.q D: cause illness E: cause accidents<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Option A - Damage<n><n>Drugs such as marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamine, heroin, opium, caffeine, and painkillers can cause brain damage.<n><n>---<n>#### Option B - Cloud<n><n><n>### Reference: <n><n>Drugs including hallucinogens, opiates, anxiolytics and sedatives, and stimulants decrease the body's ability to function on its own. When that happens, the brain needs to function on its own and make important decisions for itself. Decisions include maintaining an adequate level of concentration when focusing, and being able to stay alert and conscious.<n><n>---<n><n>Drugs affect all physical and body functions, making them less effective. The brain is a big part of this. The brain helps regulate and control almost every part of the body.<n><n>---<n>---<n><n>### Drug Classifications:<n><n>* Stimulants – include amphetamines (speed), cocaine, ecstasy, and over-the-counter medications – have properties that increase the rate at which messages are sent between the brain and the body.<n>* Depressants – include alcohol, opiates, cannabis and prescription medications – slow the rate at which messages between the body and the brain travel, leading to a sense of calm, relaxation, and a decrease in anxiety.<n><n>### Additions:<n><n>* Hallucinogens – mushrooms and LSD can produce a distorted sense of reality or “fantasy”.<n>* Steroids – performance-enhancing drugs and corticosteroids help the body produce proteins and can boost sports performance.<n><n><n>----------<n><n>### Task:Write questions for the information in each paragraph. Write complete subject and predicate questions for each paragraph.<n><n>Paragraph 1:There are many different kinds of drugs, though they can be grouped into three main categories: stimulants, depressants, and hallucinogens. These drugs can be classified into sub-groups that are further distinguished by how they affect the body. Drug addiction is a chronic disorder that usually affects an unknown number of people. Once someone has become addicted to a drug, quitting is extremely tough. Many

In London, a bus leaves from City Hall in London heading to the City of Bath every day at noon and arrives in Bath at 7 PM.  What time is sunset in the city of Bath, on the day of arrival of the arriving bus?<n><n>### Response 1: In the city of Bath, the sun sets at 7:45 PM.<n><n>### Notes:<n><n>1. Make sure you do not write "day" in your answer, even though it is correct. <n><n>	1. Since both cities are in NY, the day of the bus' arrival in London has nothing to do with whether the bus will be leaving London the next day. <n><n>	2. The answer for this question is correct as long as you correctly write two bus arrivals, one to the City of London, and the other to the City of Bath.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:The people in class were instructed to brainstorm ideas, how would they use their minds for this? Choices:  A: shake hands B: control events C: talk to each other D: think creatively E: dress themselves<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Part 1<n><n>This question asked how much money we would earn if we sold of our seashells. The answer should be $54 because we sold 30 seashels and each seashell we sold cost $1.20.<n><n>#### Part 2<n><n>This question is easy to understand. This question wanted to know how many fish we had after we caught all the fish. We started with 9 fish (Jordan and Perry caught 4 fish and each of their fish was worth double). One-fourth equals 3 fish. The answer is 9 fish.<n><n>#### Part2<n><n>This question could be answered by knowing how to subtract. Jordan caught 4 and Perry caught double what he did. The question wanted to know how long the shadows from the buildings. This question is simple, it asked for hours and the answer was 360(4x5).<n><n>#### Part2 <n><n>We could answer this question for how much the people in the story would earn, if we knew the population size and hourly wage. This question wants us to compare how the two people used their minds. This is a trick question, since the question was not asking how they used their minds, but rather how they use their minds. Since the class was learning about brainstorming, I believe choice A was the correct answer.<n><n>### Part3: <n><n><n>

Mark one answer, A or B. If none are correct, select C.<n><n><n>Answer<n>[C] Not enough information to say.<n><n><n>## [Instruction] Write a program that tests an input string. Change the first letter from uppercase to lowercase (for example, "ABC" would become "abc"). If the first letter is not a lowercase letter, write, "Sorry, you entered something that is not a lowercase alphabetical character." If a letter is removed, write, "Sounds tough." If the string contains lowercase letters only, write, "That's pretty good."<n><n>Explanation<n>You will need two variables. The first variable (s), representing the string needs to be declared, and then assigned a value by reading from the keyboard. The second variable (i), representing an index from 1 to the length of the string needs to be assigned the index to the first letter of the string. The third variable (c), standing for "the character entered," also representing any alphabetic character entered, needs to be assigned to whatever the user types in. There needs to be three conditions, which are if the first letter of the s string is not a lowercase character, write "Sorry, you had an uppercase alphabetical character." if the first letter of s is lowercase, write "That sounds cool." if the first letter is a delete, write "Hey, I know that's tough to deal with."<n><n>```python<n>import sys<n>string = ''<n>character = ''<n><n>def remove_lower(letter, s):<n>    if i==len(s):<n>        print('No such character')<n>    else:<n>        s[i] = s[i+1]<n>    i += 1<n><n>def remove_upper(c, s):<n>    string = string + s[i:len(s)]<n>    i += 3<n>

Choices: A.  137.5 inches B.  144 inches C.  163 inches D.  142.5 inches E.  140 inches<n><n>###Response Y:  144<n><n>### Reasioning: Divide each side by 12 and get each inches for 1 foot.  Then find to the closest to the height.  If he was 164 inches he would get it right.

Choices:  A: restaurant B: basement C: all buildings D: carpet E: synagogue<n><n>### Response:		The correct choice is all buildings. Floors are kept clean in restaurants, basements, synagogues, and in holy places such as the Carpet building.<n><n>### Input<n>I am writing a program that will return a percentage of a number based on the input of an integer between 0 and 100.<n><n>### Code<n><n>```python<n>def percentCheck(vali,percent):<n>	if type(percent)=="float":<n>		if type(vali)=="int":<n>			return "%.1f"%(percent/vali)<n>	else:<n>		if type="int":<n>	    return "%.0d"%(percent/int(vali))<n>```<n><n>### Problem<n>There is a problem with this code. When I run it, it's returning the correct percentage based on the input. An example if when the input was 1, it returned 100. When the input was 10, it returned 1. When I run it in my browser, it gives the correct output. I cannot figure out what's wrong.<n><n>(Hint: Think about what happens when a value is out of range)<n><n>### Solution<n>The output to your percentCheck function should be a string, not a float. If the value of 'percent' is larger than the value of the 'vali', then you'll get a divide-by-zero error, and you will need to cover your bases and either round to the nearest one, give no output, or check the value of the percentage before you divide by 'vali' and make sure it's less than 1 before dividing. Since the input to the function must be an 'int' you need to make sure the percentage is a float and not an integer.

Choices:  A: condition heart B: expend energy C: laugh D: stretch E: weigh<n><n>### Response:		Option A <n><n>### Sample answer:<n><n>* Condition heart: Exercise is an important form of preventative health care. It improves overall blood flow throughout the entire body and maintains arterial flexibility. Regular exercise is a common means of preventing and managing heart disease, such as cardiac damage from a high blood pressure reading.<n>*Exercise also keeps up overall energy levels which can help addicts fight the fatigue and depression often attributed to addiction.<n>* Exercise allows addicts to release chemicals in the brain and body including endorphins which reduce stress and increase positive emotions. This helps addicts feel happier and more focused.<n>

Which number is bigger, the difference multiplied by one hundred or one hundred times the difference?<n><n>### Response<n><n>The difference is smaller by one order of magnitude than it is when you multiply the two numbers.<n><n>Answer B is incorrect because when you multiply two numbers, the difference remains unchanged. Answers A, C, and D are incorrect because although the difference between them might increase, it cannot be 1% of either of those numbers.

Choices:  A: botanic garden B: flower garden C: backyard D: supermarket E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Option A: a botanic garden<n><n>The botanic garden may have varieties of roses that are not commonly found at other places.<n><n>#### Option B: a flower garden<n><n>A flower garden may have varieties that were brought home from other places.<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a response that appropriately complete the request.<n><n>#### Option C: the backyard<n><n>You might find variety of roses in your backyard.<n><n>#### Option D: a supermarket<n><n>You might be able to purchase a variety of roses as a gift at a supermarket.<n><n>#### Option E: the outdoors<n><n>You might find a variety of roses while taking a walk or being outdoors.<n><n>---<n>

Choices:  A: at the zoo B: south carolina C: hen house D: louisiana E: arkansas<n><n>### Response:		Finding the appropriate command.<n><n>### Input<n><n>How many times is the string "abcde" included in the string "abcddeefg"?<n><n>### Response<n><n>```<n>Let's first remove the characters that are not within the answer to get to only include `abcddeefg`.<n><n>'bcdde'.split('')<n><n>Let's now loop through removing all elements after the answer string, but first converting it to a list of characters:<n><n>['abcde', 'efg']<n><n>Let's loop through, remove those characters and see if the result is the string we were looking for:<n><n>def isAllIncluded(answer, test):<n>  answersList = answer.split('')<n>  testList = test.split('')<n><n>  answer = ''.join(answersList)<n>  #This test will remove from `answer` the characters that<n>  #are not within the answer to be compared to `test`.<n>  test = ''.join(testList[:-1])<n>  <n>  return (answer+test+'').find(''.join(testList[1:])) > -1<n><n>```<n>### Input: What is the sum of the strings "bear", "sled", "snow", and "carpet"?<n><n>### Output: 76<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a program that determines whether or not the numbers are odd.<n><n>### Output Format:<n><n>Print a value of true or false depending on whether or not the numbers provided are odd.<n><n><n>### Solution:<n><n>Define the following code in Python. Test it on input data.<n><n><n>## Instruction:<n><n>Finding the appropriate command to match the input data.<n><n>### Instrutcion:<n><n>Given the list `["Alice", 28, "Bob", 78, "Carol", 69]`, what is the longest name?<n><n>### Output<n><n>Return a number representing the longest name in the provided array.<n><n>output: `78`<n><n>### Output format<n><n>Return the length of the array representing each name so that the list is sorted in descending numerical order.<n><n><n>## Solution:<n><n><n>### Input:`["Alice",<n> 28,<n> "

Take emergency contraception, which, like contraception, is safe for women to use multiple times.<n>3. Not have sex that cycle<n><n>If you take emergency contraception, you won't be able to get pregnant from having sex again until the pill has cleared your body.<n><n>Emergency contraception is less effective if you leave it too long to use it.<n><n>If I had a new partner, with whom I hadn't planned on having sex, but I didn't have contraception, I could also choose to not have sex with my new partner.<n><n>### InputWhere would you get a condom? Choices:  A: modern house B: building C: townhouse D: neighbor's house E: downtown<n><n>### Response:		 It was a modern house. <n><n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Write a program that accepts one or more commands and executes each command appropriately.<n><n>A command consists of the command word and any necessary arguments. Each command is prefixed on a single line and must be an ordered, natural language sentence. The command word is not an argument to the command; its only purpose is to help identify the given command.<n><n>The input consists of a sequence of commands to be executed. The commands are split into lines that consist either of a single command word separated by spaces or two sequential words.<n><n>A command begins with a line containing the command word by itself. If this line does not match the name of a command, the program exits with status code 1. Otherwise, it executes the command. For example, to list all the commands and their associated status code, the input will be:<n><n>```<n>help<n>list<n>exit<n>```<n><n>Any lines following the command line are ignored during execution and are simply output from the program. To ensure this, the command word is the only thing on a line that is considered command input, while everything else considered input is a line of text. For instance, the input<n><n>```<n>exit<n>help<n>list<n>```<n><n>is actually equivalent to<n><n>```<n>exit (help or list or something else)<n>```<n><n>which is considered command text, not command input.<n><n>A command can either be specified with no arguments or with any number of arguments. When there are no arguments, the arguments are empty in other words, they cannot be used by anything but the command interpreter.<n><n>When an argument contains spaces, the positional argument is separated by these spaces and is assigned to the variable name. The variable name consists of one or more lowercase letters only separated with the character `-`, and the value can be any one of the following:<n><n>* a single literal text string, which will be output as a command argument<n>* a variable name, followed by the character `=`, and followed by a space and the value, which will be output into that variable. The variable name cannot match a function name, nor can the variable name contain a period. This value can be anything that can be assigned to a variable, such as any type of number or a list.<n>* a variable name without the character `=` or other special characters, or a command or function.<n><n>To list all the

Choices:  A: small B: underground C: high D: huge E: tall<n><n>### Response:		A, Empire State Building is in New York. There are many tall buildings in New York City (New York, America). How much more money each Doberman pup earned compared to each Schnauzer (doberman and Schnauzer money) <n><n>### Example:<n>The following example shows how a solution to the problem is executed.<n><n>```<n>doberman_money = 25<n>schnauzer_money = 45<n><n>Money total = doberman_money + schnauzer_moneiy<n><n>difference = doberman_total - schnauzer_total<n><n>Doberman_result = doberman_financial_gain/total_amount<n>Schnauzer_result = schnauzer_financial_loss/total_amount<n><n>```<n><n>### Output<n>```<n>Result = Doberman_result + Schnauzer_result<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:The snake was a cottonmouth.  It was an American, from where? Choices:  A: georgia B: tree C: nature D: under the rocks E: france<n><n>### Response:		B

On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:A person writes a check to a clerk, where does the clerk put them? Choices:  A: cash register B: desk drawer C: pay envelope D: throw away E: box<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Input<n>When writing a check, the clerk is supposed to put all the necessary information on it, including the account number, your company’s logo, your company name, and the amount written on the check in a specified amount of money; the clerk will then mail the check to your company, as long as the check is not too large.<n><n>### Response and Explanation<n>I believe that the person asked for has a business that requires them to write checks, like a school cafeteria, or a restaurant, because they are asking for who put the information in the check, and how they are placed; however we can say that the clerk is the one who puts all the information on the check like the account number, the company logo, your company name and the amount of money written on the check. After the person writes the check, the clerk goes through the process and puts the check in a drawer or a cash register.<n><n><n>### Input <n>How many 6-foot-tall people can be seen standing in front of each window if there are exactly 30 windows?  What if there are exactly 25 windows?<n><n>### Response<n>C<n><n>### Reasons<n>The reason we can state this number is because we know that we need exact 30 windows and each window must have 5 people standing in front of it, so the person in front of the 1st window must be the 1st person we can add up to 5 people standing infront of 5 windows, then it will repeat itself till you have reached the exact amount of 30 windows with 5 people; 30+30+30, add two 30s and it equal 60 people standing infront of the 30 windows.<n><n>### Input A person gets to pick any two numbers from 1 to 100. What are the probability of picking and getting a perfect square? Choices: A: 0 B: 1 C: 100 D: 49<n><n>### Reponse B<n><n>### Exaplanation<n>The answer that makes the most sense is the number 49, because a perfect square has to end in the number 49; and the probability of a number ending up in a square that ends in 4

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:What is love when everyone keeps feeling it? Choices:  A: contagious B: wrong C: last forever D: painful E: blind<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Demonsration:<n>A:  contagious<n>B:  wrong<n>C:  last forever<n>D:  painful<n>E:  blind<n><n>### Input :A person is 24 feet tall. Every second, they grow by 1/10 foot. A person also stands at 1 foot for every 1.3 second. What is this person's height at 1 hour, 10 minutes, and 15 seconds after noon?<n><n>Answer : 370 feet and 37 seconds<n><n>### Demosration:<n>Ans = ( (24 *2) * ( 1.00 * 60 )  +  ( 24 * 1 ) *  ( 1.01 * 60 )   ) - ( 24 * ( 1.3 * 60 ) ) <n>= 13.04*100<n>= 1304.00<n><n>### Explanation :<n>As each second person increases as 1/10 of the total height but it's base time is 1 feet, then each second it will increase as 1/17 feet in each second but their base time is 7 second, thus by 10 sec person will increase as 1*7 that means an increase of 7 feet, thus 10th second of the increase =7.<n><n>Next a person is 22 feet long, but every 1.3 seconds it increases, thus after 5 seconds it is 22+5=27. It's 5th second of increment = (22*1*5)/360 seconds = 1/9 or 1/360<n><n>Thus after 5 min = (15*1/360)/360=15/360th of a seconds<n><n>Next 10 minutes = ( 15/ 360)*10 = 15*1/60/360th/360  i.e the person 22-feet would be increased as  15*1/ 360*10=15/6000th of a foot<n><n>Now 10 min +15/6

If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:The delivery man was delivering a whole crate of shampoo, they went through a lot of it at the what? Choices:  A: supermarket B: motel C: at hotel D: shampoo bottle E: hair salon<n><n>### Response:		<n>If we knew the number of shampoo<n>The shampoo is from one number to the next number like 1,2,3,4,5 and so on. If we know the number then we can guess what number we should get the next number because there will always be an increase that’s how it goes from 1 to 2 to 3 to 4 to 5 or more. However, the same number will always be the minimum. If the current number in our example is the minimum number, then the next number should be the current number plus one.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>1. 97698<n>2.2257345464743<n><n>### Credits: <n>Cody Hodges for teaching me and others coding<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90. If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: Dr. Banks had 330 toothbrushes to give away to his patients. He gave away 53 toothbrushes in January. He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:James didn't know what to do.  He felt that he'd ruin his relationship with Jen if he took it further, and he didn't want to do that.  At the same time,  He fight that pushing farther might do what to something good? Choices:  A: found B: destroy C: construct D: fix E: produce<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>D: fix<n>A: found<n>E: produce<n>C: construct<n>B: destroy<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>In 2015, 1,128 miles of bike trails in Chicago were closed.  There were an additional 333 miles of bike trailes in the suburbs of Chicago.  Choose the letter that represents a multiple choice question. Choices: A. How many miles of bike trailles in Chicago in 2015? B. How many more miles of bike traiel in the suburbs than Chicago. C. How many miles less of bike trail in the suburbs in 2017? D. How many miles of suburban bike traiels in 2012?<n>```<n><n>## Solution:<n>If in 2016 there are 333 less trails than in 2014, and 4 times as many as in 2013, then in 2011 how many bike trails are there?<n><n>## Analysis:<n><n>You can solve these types of problems by drawing the information out and setting up a mathematical formula that gives you the correct answer. However, most people don't use this technique because it takes longer to do, and it's easy to get lost in all the numbers<n><n>### Solution 1<n><n>First, draw out my formula to match with 2017. <n><n>1128 / 3 = [n1 = Number in 2018] <n>    3: [n2 = Number in 217]<n>    4: [n3 = Number in 255]<n><n>Next, set up the formula. <n><n>1n1 - 2n2 + 3n3 = 0<n><n><n>1n1 == 2n2 + x<n><n>n1 == (2n2+X) / 1<n><n><n>1 / 1 * n1 == 2 / 2 * n2 + x<n>    2n2 = 2 + x * 1 <n>    2 + 1 / x<n>x = 2 + (1 / 2)<n>X = 3<n><n>-1/2 is subtracted so we have something on the RIGHT side.<n><n>Fin

On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon. Choices:  A: see king B: hello C: meow D: drink water E: live many years<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>```<n>Expected outcome:<n>A: see king<n>```<n><n>```<n>Explanation:<n><n>A:<n>```<n><n>```python<n>def say(A):<n>    if A=='A':<n>        return'see king'<n><n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>### What would you normally expect a person to say?<n><n>### Response<n><n>```<n>Expectation:B<n>```<n><n>```py<n>def say(C):<n>    if C=='A':<n>           return B<n>```<n><n># 2019-05-09 (Wed)<n>### Task:<n>Read the Python code in the file titled 'Hello.py'. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon. Choices: <n>Left: (the train is facing north) A.<n>Right: (the train is not facing east) B.<n>Backward (a boat is at a river) C.<n><n>### Response<n>A.<n><n>### Submissions:<n>### aadf9b8a2c955b2c8471b46943c01e97<n><n>### In the game, if you make a move, which in turn, moves their king into your checkmate, how many moves on average do you think it will take you to checkmate your opponent?<n><n>### Answer:<n>- First, you will need to find where the King is, which is half the board (for an eight by eight board).<n>- You will need two adjacent squares to use to make an enclosure.<n>- You will need to capture the king.<n>- After making an enclosure, the kings remaining options are to castle, or be taken.<n>- If its not a good time to castle, you will need to take the King.<n><n>### Question: What is the minimum number of times you need to move the pawn to the other side of the board?<n><n>### First, 1 if the pawn reaches the other side of the chess board, as they can only move in a straight line, it would have to pass 16 squares.<n><n>### Now, to actually answer the question, we first see how many moves it takes to capture a queen. In this case, let us say that we capture the queen, and have the pawn in the middle of the board, the queen would have taken 2 times the amount of squares that we captured it from the pawn, therefore taking more 4 squares.<n><n>- The pawn starts at (1, 1), which is the first square in the bottom row.<n>- Let the pawn start moving left starting from square one (2,2)<n>  - Square 2<n>  - If captured

He gave away 67 toothbrushes in February. In March he gave away 46 toothbrushes. In April and May, he gave away the remaining toothbrushes, half each month.  How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. Jordan caught 4 fish and Perry caught double what Jordan caught. On the way back to shore, the boat tipped over and they lost one-fourth of their total catch. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:Nowadays people have smart ones, but at one time it was cutting edge to have a tiny calculator on your what? Choices:  A: mobile phone B: wristwatch C: briefcase D: office E: desktop<n><n>### Response:		I am not sure what kind of calculator you are referring to, but if it was a tiny calculator on a person's wrist, then it would be a wristwatch.<n><n>### Input:(In this question, you should answer like this: “The time has come to ask the question with the greatest impact on a person's life, so he or she must answer “I do!”) "Would you like to spend the rest of your lives together?"<n>### Demon:You should answer with a “Yes!” for this question.<n><n>## Input:<n>* When you multiply one number by another number, what do you get?<n>* (Choices: A: A multiplication table B: A calculator C: The two numbers D: A computer E: An equation)<n><n>## Demonstration:When you multiply two numbers, you get the product.<n><n>## Input:(In this question you should answer like this, “I believe that my answer is ________.”<n><n>## Demon:If you believe that your answer is 100, then you should indicate in your answer that you think your answer is equal to 100.<n>###Input:(In this question, there is one choice, for example: "The answer is incorrect.")  “The answer to the multiplication problem 5 times one is:”<n>### Demon:(The answer the question is: 5 times one is equal to 5.)<n><n>###Input:The rule is: a(b) = ab<n><n>###Demonstration(a(b) = ab)<n><n>### Input:"I am not sure if _______ is a square of a product, because ______ is a product of a number and a square."<n>### Demon(It is not a square of a product because multiplication does not yield a square. Multiplication just yields the product.)<n><n>### Input(The answer to the subtraction problem 32-6 is: )<n>### Demon You should get the answer to that problem to be 26.)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>### Answer:(When you add 5 to the number 9, the result is 14.)<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Instuctions:(Which operation will give you this output? 20-7)<n>###

On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:John hated mosquitoes.  It wasn't the bloodsucking that he disliked, it was that the insects made what? Choices:  A: fly B: buzz C: move D: honey E: help flowers pollenate<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demorstration:<n>In 19 minutes the sun will be directly in the center of the sky<n>So at 2:19 the sun will directly in the center of he sky with a height of 31.57 degrees<n>The angle x (where we are looking from the sun (where the sun is directly in the center of his sky)) and angle y (where we are from the horizon which is 0 degrees) can be calculated using the following formula<n>   [Angular Formulas]<n>where x is the angle or where we are looking from the center of the sky(where the sun is directly the center of the sky), y is the angle or where point is in the sun's rays on the horizon, θ is the angle or the height of the sun in the sky(where we are directly looking at the sun, and it is directly in the center). (You might be thinking this is similar to the sum of the interior and exterior angles of a triangle but is different)<n>To understand this I will first assume the sun is in the center of that sky, it is noon, the sun's height is 76 degrees.<n>(the sun height can be written as H = 76 degrees + δ where δ is the error or the height of the object in the sky that is not directly in the center)<n><n>This is what I got:<n>    x = 48.07 degrees<n>    y = 0.00 degrees<n>   [Calculation]<n>Now let us reapply the formulas to get the sun's angle on the horizon and the sun's angle directly in the center:<n>    y = tan(tan(π/4))<n>    y=1.4287<n>\$\cos(y\times27^o)-\sin(y\times25^o+11)\$<n><n>I get<n><n>    Cos[(ac+bc)\*(27/180)\*\*\^(\)*\*sin \*\*((b/2-a/2)^2\*(180-a-b))^/180)]=sin \*\* (\*\*((b/4-a/4)^2\*(145+a+b)/180)^/180)<n>    	[Equation]<n>    Cos(36.

How many more toothbrushes did Dr. Banks give out in the busiest month versus the slowest month?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Sally picks 30 seashells on Monday. On Tuesday, she picks half as many seashells as she did on Monday. If she can sell each seashell for $1.20, how much money can she make if she sells all of her seashells?<n>Answer: 54<n><n>Input: Jordan and Perry took a boat out to the lake to go fishing on a Monday morning. How many fish remain?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: Every hour past noon shadows from a building stretch an extra 5 feet, starting at zero at noon.  How long are the shadows from the building 6 hours past noon in inches?<n>Answer: 360<n><n>### Input:The woman experienced great joy, but despite that this was a what? Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n><n>### Response:		<n>A, the correct answer is "bathe". Cats don't bathe, or they at least would probably need to be told how to do it. Bats don't either. We humans do, but the cat needs to be told what to do, and since the cat already knows what to do, it must be a mistake with the statement. Also, since we humans would need to be told what to bath in, it must be non-fluid in nature and we don't die of cancer from bathing, nor do any animals, since the humans are the ones that die from cancer. So, John must be bathing some type of animal that needs a bath.<n>

Choices:  A: rain forest B: tree tops C: toy store D: zoological gardens E: great outdoors<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is B.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The captive monkey is found in a tree top habitat. Since the tree tops are in the tree but not attached to the ground its considered to be in the air outside the building but not outside the tree itself. A captive monkey is only found in a zoo as it does not live in the wild.<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input:<n>### Demonstiation:<n>Input: Which statement is true? Choices: <n><n>1. There is a 45% chance that Mary will have to stay in school late tomorrow.<n>2. There is a 12% chance of snow tomorrow.<n>3. Mary is not very lucky.<n>4. Mary is very lucky.<n><n>#### Demonstration: The correct option is 2.<n><n>### Demo:<n>### Explanations:<n><n>* 1. There is a a 45% chances of Mary going home in the afternoon so Mary has the chance of going home early. <n>* 2. There is a snowday if there is snow in Atlanta. Snow is highly unlikely.<n>* 3. Mary hasn't been lucky lately so its probably not going to work out well for her.<n>* 4. Given input 2 and 12, your output should return -11 and 915.<n><n>```<n>public static int getMinutesBetweenHours(int h) {<n>    if (h == 0) return 0;<n>   if (h == 12) return 1439; // 30 - 12 = 18 ; 18*2 = 36;  12 + 36 = 48; 1439/24 = 59.2960937;<n>    if(h!= 12) {<n>        return h - 0.5;<n>    }<n>```<n><n>Given a number input, add 500 to the input and divide the sum by 10. For example, 6908 / 10 = 790.690897477/100 = 79.06908980845 = 79.<n><n>```<n><n>public static int addDivide(int number) {<n>	int addition = number + 500;<n>	int division = addition/10;<n>	System.out.println(division);<n>}<n>```<n><n>Give a program to convert Fahrenheit to Celcius and Celcius to Fahrenheit.
